description: Walking into Spec's is like time-traveling back into the days of the Beat Generation. Come here to drink a pint of beer, browse the antique photographs, and converse with 1 or 2 regulars who most certainly can tell you a tale of old San Francisco.
author: Cody W.

description: This was the second bar on a night of wandering. It was recommended by a bartender from the first bar. She described it as "a cool weird spot", so curiously we wanted to check it out. The place is filed with various quirky decor, dimly lit and offered a mixed crowd. One of the bartenders had a nice heavy hand when making the drinks. Cool different place to check out.
author: Claudiana C.

description: We were introduced to this place on a guided tour. It was a fun atmosphere with a ton of interesting stuff to see and me and my group of friends  were enjoying ourselves until the owner of the bar decided to tell us essentially we were being too loud and that no one else was able to enjoy their time. I would never go back just because of her, she was beyond rude and unwelcoming. Not to mention we ran into her at another bar where she continued her rudeness, and attempted to have us removed from there. So I have to say overall it was a horrible experience! If I could give no stars I would.
author: Dana Z.

description: No! Walk away as you stand there thinking that this might be an interesting experience. It's not! Save your money and your time.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Specs is a quintessential San Francisco bar and a must-visit on any traveler's itinerary.  It's conveniently located across the street from City Lights Books... In the Beat Generation neighborhood in North Beach.

This is a place that you can visit with your friends and not be distracted by televisions, sports or overly loud music.

 The decor is wonderfully San Francisco rustic - lots of memorabilia and curiosities to entertain the eye.  Check out the supposed whale bone behind the bar.

It's an easy, comfortable place to go to by yourself, and strike up a conversation with some of the regulars, young and old.  

The bartenders are welcoming, responsive and generally easy to talk to.  During our visit, bartender Tony immediately engaged is with a smile, a well mixed cocktail delivered with the latest if his jokes.
author: Patty S.

description: It feels like you are waking back into time when you walk into Specs. It is really old and you can marvel at all the memorabilia on the walls.  It feels like you're walking into a haunted house when going to the bathrooms.  I've often seen women take a wrong turn into the guys room due to lack of signage.  I enjoy the $4 draft beer which is available all the time. See you soon Specs.
author: Paul S.

description:
This was a cool place to hang out.  Located in North beach, very accessible and surrounded by many other bars and restaurants. The space inside is nice and was pretty busy on a late Wednesday night too and that says something! We just got drinks here and it was a fun time. The interior is very interesting giving it a nice dive bar feel. Some of my friends think it's one of the most fun bars in the city! They had a good selection of drinks and the bathrooms were not terrible so that was a plus. 

Will hang out here again and recommend it to all !
author: Shivani B.

description:
I've only been here once and I was very disappointed.

It looks quite cool and the decoration is all weird and fun. It's the kind of bar I would usually love, but the drinks were terrible. The gin & tonics were awful. 

So, unfortunately I have to give it three stars, and that's just because the place looks cool.
author: Marta F.

description: I came in there for the first time and was laughing with my colleagues and got asked "be quiet you're being too loud" followed up by a rude man asking me if I'm leaving. They also handed me a card that said "the gentlemen prefers to sulk in silence" on my way out. Horrible etiquette and not the way to treat paying customers. If 0 stars were an option it would be the choice. Posting the picture of the card in addition to this.
author: Nick D.

description:
A group of friends suggested me to go here as it's a hidden traditional gem bar, in the middle of a fairly touristic neighborhood.. and they were right!

The bar is really cool, with unique decorations. You can get lots in looking at all the ephemera on walls and ceiling! 

The night I was there a guy was sharing watercolor and making art, inviting guests to join and help him - and it was so much fun. 

Beers are cheap. A great bar to hang!
author: Martina C.

description: Just moved to the area and was looking for Guinness on tap.  Wandered into the bar and was ignored for 10 minutes.  Other people came in after and were served.  Finally a gentleman who was on break served me - no apologies and little acknowledgment - just a scowl.   Pardon me for being new to the neighborhood.  Likely won't be back. Not a friendly place.
author: Robert C.

description:
3.5 stars

Well drinks come in a small ass glass that's gone in about five sips and at $7 what is up with that? 

Credit card minimum is also $20 so that's a bummer but they do pitchers for beers

Seating is good towards the back for larger groups 

Hidden spot off the beaten path despite it's close proximity to Devil's Acre 

Overall Thoughts

I really wanted to like Specs with all its charm but the price point makes it hard to be a go-to spot
author: Eddie W.

description: Yo, this is like a crazy blast from the past type of place... the music, the decorations, the people... I drank some beers and ate cheese and crackers. I would go back again. Cheers, friends.
author: Lewis G.

description: Anyone who gave this place less than five stars is out of their mind; decently priced draft beers and so many interesting characters. This dive bar is the epitome of non-gentrified SF. Read about the history of this place is you need further convincing.
author: Emily H.

description: The SF everyone says is dying, dead and gone lives on forever at Specs.
author: Sally R.

description:
Congratulations to Spec's on its legacy businesses status and the new 10-year lease. I strongly believe North Beach would be missing something special without you. 

While by no means my regular watering hole, I appreciate that it's such a neighborhood stalwart that you can stop by no matter how long between visits, and still feel lost in time - like nothing has changed. No nonsense, straight forward, classic bar with the occasional tune on the old piano in the back, Spec's makes a great spot for a low key post-work happy hour. Check out the tchotchkes. The nostalgic charm of the place is a bonus. Also love the humor and attitude of their sandwich boards.

Spec's new lease keeps the spirit of the Beat poet movement alive along with Vesuvio and City Lights Bookstore that give North Beach much charm. Cheers to 10 more years!
author: Jon L.

description:
White Russians, crazy crap all over the walls, plastic bins of Ritz crackers and partial blocks of cheese, cash only.

That about sums Specs' up. 
That and it's just perfect. 

On a Saturday night my party of 7 was able to snag a large round table, several plastic bins of Ritz and cheese, and round of white Russians in mere minutes of walking in. It's dark interior is offset with what is clearly some very colorful history at this local dive. A total win and the first of many visits for this gal.
author: Candice G.

description: I've been a patron at specs for 20 years it's my favorite bar along with the Saloon over on grant Avenue in North Beach.  Always an interesting crowd and pretty much absent of pretension, great bar staff.
author: Bruce Z.

description:
Note:  for first timers - cash only (ATM inside)
I met a friend here that I hadn't seen in 35 years, and I was so pleased he picked this spot.  Hate to call it a dive, but let's say, rustic San Francisco.  Fun, fun place to throw back a pint or six or be a hipsters and go with a $3 Hamm's.  Either way, you won't be disappointed.  Actual comment from another friend of mine from San Francisco "OMG - Spec's - I went there YEARS ago - so much fun!"  Well, it was apparently fun then, and it's definitely fun now.
author: Patrick K.

description: Cool place to get a drink. Love the decor and the laid back atmosphere. Would def come back.
author: Linda H.

description:
Dark, divey, gritty, musty, & cluttered.  

That's just all a part of its particular brand of charm.  

If you want hipster, this isn't your joint.

If you want old school, then it is.

Loaded w history, culture, & artists, Specs' is an institution, both the bar & the man!

I met Specs (Simmons) back in the 90's, & 2 things were constant...
his looming presence, & his love for the ladies.

Today, he doesn't get around as much as he used to, but his love for the ladies is still going strong.

Conveniently located right next to Tosca, & right across the street from City Lights Books, a stop here is a must for any local, artist, neighborhood newbie, or tourist.

In other words, 
anyone.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: My boyfriend, a friend, and I visited on a Tuesday evening and were able to grab a table and quickly order drinks. The bartender was friendly and the prices were unbeatable. (He also had a heavy pour!) This is my kind of bar, all the way: no frills, cheap drinks, good people.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Specs' is a local legend. Stocked with every conceivable oddity, this museum of eternal ephemera is brimming with lovable grumps and local legends. The cheese plate usually sucks - so consider yourself warned. Unless you love stale saltines and wax-on gouda. Hey, I'm not here to judge. 
Used to live just up the hill from this place and worked right across the street at City Lights, so this was on my evening itinerary quite often. 

Specs' is a quirky character of a bar. Enjoy the weird appeal and do try to learn something from the odd exhibit of artifacts. There's actually a lot of interesting SF history in there.
author: Carole B.

description: Stumbled upon this hidden corner bar, just what we were looking for. Easy going, eclectic ambiance and great people watching.
author: Rachel P.

description: This place is incredible. Amazing vibes and really great people. Rich with history. Kind and friendly bartender. It's a must go! A well kept secret. Only for the best of people :)
author: Hannah B.

description:
Cheap drinks, colorful patrons, salty bartenders, and plenty of cheese & crackers for the table. These are just some of the reasons why Specs' remains of of my favorite (cash-only) dive bars in North Beach.

I used to frequent this bar a lot back when I lived in the hood 15-years ago. Located across the street from City Lights Bookstore, this watering hole really transports you the SF of yesteryear (if that's a word). I'm pleased to report that 15-years later, Specs is still the same. Nothing (and I mean NOTHING) has changed about this place. The gruff bartenders still give you dirty looks if you take too long to order or request a frou-foru drink. This place is strictly beer and hard booze, folks. If you want a fancy-schmancy Cosmo or Apple-tini, go to Tosca's next door.

My group of 7 and I squatted at a round table last Saturday night. We nursed a bunch of White Russians and Fernet, while nibbling on blocks of cheese. There's plenty of people-watching to be done at Specs. And by that, I mean there are a number or irregular regulars (everyone from Beatniks to hipsters to borderline hobos). That being said, everyone seems to play nice in the same sandbox.

If you're looking for an authentic North Beach experience, do yourself a favor and mosey down this little alley way for a pop. You'll be glad you did.
author: Kevin B.

description: If you're in the neighborhood and in the mood for a little bar hopping, I'd recommend visiting both Vesuvio and Specs!  Specs is across the street from Vesuvio.  Both are really unique; much different from the other club-like or upscale bars in the area.  Down to earth, gritty and historical.  Just don't ask for a martini here!!  They don't like to make martinis.
author: Poppy B.

description:
Love this local bar next to Tosca cafe. This was a welcoming change after escaping from the noisy Tosca cafe Friday night. When I walked in, I was overtaken by the quaintness of this cozy bar. this place has so many eclectic items collected from all corners of the world, neatly spread through the walls, in the cabinets, from the ceiling, without cluttering the place.

Even though this place didn't have my usual requirements of good wine/cocktail, I still was happily sitting on the stool, sipping some water, and feeling happy to have been taken to such a cute and low key joint, unbeknownst to the hipsters next door.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Violent?

I have been coming to Specs for years. I had always loved going there as it was a little hidden gem in that tourist ridden area.   The last couple of years, the clientele has changed a bit.   After a long night we ended up there on New Year's. I ran to the ladies room as they were yelling for last call.  While I was in there I could hear two women verbally and physically abusing another woman and could tell it was getting violent and racial.  As I was stepping out a man walked by the ladies room and the women jumped him.  One started hitting him and the other knocked him down the stairs.  I'm not going to lie, I got around it as fast as possible.  I ran and told my husband.  He saw the guy come flying down the stairs and was trying to help him. We tried to tell the bartenders but they were more concerned with kicking everyone out.  We waited outside to see what was happening.  The man who had been attacked was trying to call the police and waiting for her to come out.  The bar managers kept saying they wanted nothing to do with it, even though it happened right in front of them.  The woman in the restroom who had been getting attacked prior to that came out and started telling people what happened as well.  She said that the bartenders were not letting the attacker out as she was "afraid" people were waiting for her, and they were trying to let her out the back door.  When people started knocking on the door, the bartenders said that it was not their responsibility that these people were attacked there and they would have to handle it themselves and they let her leave without calling the police.  My husband is a lawyer and quickly grabbed the two people who had been attacked by her and gave him his card.  He does not practice this kind of litigation, but we have friends who do.  He told them because this was happening in the bar during the hours it was open it WAS ABSOLUTELY their responsibility to handle it.  Yesterday we heard from the gentleman who was pushed down the stairs, and he went to the hospital with a concussion.  My husband put him in touch with another lawyer, and apparently he is looking at suing the bar for damages.  There are so many great bars in the area, I'm thinking there are others I can go to where if something like this happens, bar management will get a handle on it. I was shocked at how badly Specs let this escalate.  Not a great way to see 2017 start. We won't be going back.
author: J J.

description: To hell with Rice-a-Roni! Specs is the true San Francisco treat! A historic dive bar with its history hanging on its walls...Consumer Warning: if dive bars aren't your thing, stay away! More info on the man and the bar:  http://m.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Bar-and-Grail-Since-1968-Specs-Twelve-Adler-2827944.php
author: Steve T.

description: Great atmosphere and great service. Good old fashioned bar you can't find anywhere else in San Francisco.
author: Josh T.

description:
I usually end up here in combo with visiting Vesuvio across the street. Spec's tends to attract a more eclectic crowd that's great for a long, fun conversation. It's darker, divier, and even more crazily decorated.

Check it out, grab a pint, and do some stranger chatting.
author: Ryan H.

description: Very cool and relaxed divey place. Enjoy coming out here but I just wish it wasn't cash only.
author: Ingrid O.

description: I've visited Spec a few times and like the low key vibe. I prefer beer over cocktails and was happy with their selection. They're reasonably priced. I like the fact that the noise level is moderate so you can have a conversation. Definitely older crowd. There's lots of cool curios to check out.
author: David F.

description:
A+ dive bar tucked in an small side street just off Columbus. Feels very old school SF. I came here to play board games with some new friends. It was quiet enough that we didn't need to screen and loud enough that I wasn't worried about other people listening in. I wasn't drinking that night, and the barkeep gave me my coffee for free. Will definitely return if I ever have need to be in the weird nether regions of Chinatown/FiDi/North Beach. 

The point is, it was a good bar in a weird spot. Or maybe it was a weird bar in a good spot. Either way. Go.
author: Allison S.

description: A great locals joint! A good look at old San Fran. The wheel of cheese is pretty cool.
author: Jill J.

description:
Specs' is San Francisco.

Since 1968  - Specs' (named after the owner Specs Simmons) has seen a vast array of poetic and bohemian characters pass through their doors.

Everywhere you look around Specs' there are stirring pieces of history or creativity which sing of San Francisco's diverse and rich history. And it's real too. Specs' has always been just a quirky and magical haven in the North Beach. It never had to try or court the San Francisco scene. The scene came to it. 

The warmness of Spec's vintage lights  highlight the art that is showcased and which unfolds here. This past weekend - we sat in the back  - and I watched as two remarkable artists became engrossed in the energy of the place and just drew. Right behind them was an old piano - which I heard comes alive on certain nights accompanied with stirring live music - which further awakens this unique space.

Old Folk music crooned throughout the place as I sipped on my hot tea (yes, tea) here. I kept on warming my hands on the hot glass full of soothing lemon - as I glanced around the room full of conversing patrons and beamed.

There was no top 40 stuff being belted through the space.

No one was wasted or stumbling to the bar.

The bartender was lovely and refilled my hot tea water throughout my time here.

Not only does Specs feel beautifully right - but it's just always been right.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Hidden gem of a bar in north beach.  
It's a locals sort of place and there are stories in these walls.... And on the walls. 
A strange nautical theme of sorts and your odd stuffed armadillo on the wall. 

Good stiff drinks here, it's cash only and I don't think there is an atm access... 
You can get Dutch cheese from the wheel and crackers though...
author: Greg F.

description:
This weekend, I totally raided a Santacon party. While I wasn't all dressed as a Santa, I got into a festive mood and dressed up. I hit North Beach up looking to meet up with my friends. My friend Jaime recommended this little pub in an alley and we headed off to Spec's.

We get there and it's filled with Santas. At the door, I'm given a "Nice" sticker. Hehe, I'll take that because even my Naughty is Nice and it's fun to play along. Oh what fun... 

It's Cash only and kinda divey, we were able to find a table in the back and have a little fun before I had to run off to dinner. Fun little place that I will keep in mind to return to again.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Dive Bar, Speakeasy, Social Club, Funky Hangout...whatever...

Specs' is a great spot tucked away next to overpriced Tosca and across from City Lights.

Warm, friendly, humble, cozy, divey...all words that come to mind when thinking about Specs.

Check it out as a great start to your tour of North Beach...or a great spot to end it.
author: Jim W.

description: Been going to Spec's for many years but no more.  Had 1 shot and one beer  THIRTEEN DOLLARS AND FIFTY CENTS!!!  Bitchy bartender says they raised the prices 60% "to keep the place open".  Too bad Spec is not still alive.  Used to be a fun place but now too expensive and sure don't want to go someplace and have the help argue with the customer.
author: R B.

description:
4:30PM.. I guess it's almost 5 o clock if you round up.
My friends and I try to find a bar and stumble upon here.
It's completely dark.
I find the bathroom and trip on the way out. I wasn't drunk yet, and the bathroom is extremely clean (note: bar just opened up).
The bartender looks like Albert Einstein.
My friends and I spent a good hour just looking at all the crap that was everywhere.
Museum, indeed.
Got a shot of Jameson (it's St. Patty's Day after all) and an Anchor Steam beer each.
14 dollars per person. Cash Only
Not sure if that's cheap.
As a bar: 3 stars. As a random hole in the wall museum that serves alcohol: 5
Regretted not sitting at the bar, Einstein looked like an interesting person
author: Trang B.

description:
This god-forsaken dive bar not only reeks of rotten fish and homeless elderly folks, but it would be generous to say that its patrons are even remotely that clean themselves. Let alone the bartenders and staff. It would be safe to assume that none of them have ever experienced one moment of happiness in their entire lives and god help you if you let them see you smile. If you so much as toast with your friends, laugh out loud at a good joke, or even make an audible noise while sipping your bud light (surprisingly there is more than PBR here) then satin-esk bartender will screech at you like a fucking demonic vulture to cease your drunken revelry. 

If you're into misery and uptight "hipsters"- this is the place for you.
author: Mike W.

description: This is my home in San Francisco. I've spent a lot of my trips trying to find a bar with some soul & history. This is the real deal. Staff is great bar is great. This is a one of a kind place you must visit while you are here. There are a lot of new bars opening up that are loosing what was great about the city and this is coming from a guy like me in my early 20's. Love this place you will too.
author: Travis W.

description:
In utero my beating heart was so so driving, urging, really. That maddening creciendo has always pounded on, even after the birth cavity; through bicycle-skinned knees, first kisses and last hugs; through, I think, a confused and utterly mesmerizing emotional trip. Clud ump clud ump clud urumpm, with slight irregularity as if to suggest something more is coming. Yes, I know, as we all do, that coming and coming is inevitably death. But, there are moments in life when the beckoning hushes and we truly rest. Mine, it just so happens, has seemed dullest while drinking whiskey, eating cheese, and reading random postcards in the hull of the mighty ship, Specs. The anti-utero, and plain-ol good joint. 

I haven't been back in 6 years, but I have written postcards to myself, sitting there six years ago. And to others, sitting there now. No stamps or pen to paper, but long mental reaches through time and space to peaceful sippers, sipping silently, quipping over the hugeness of it all. Or just getting sh$-faced on toddies.
author: Mattech S.

description: Great place to get away from hipsters and tvs. Interesting people and atmosphere.
author: Karen H.

description:
(from Nov 8 visit)
Popped in here for a quick break with a friend before heading to dinner. Didn't have a cocktail - just club soda with lime - so I can't say much about the vibe. It was $4 for 2 nonalcoholic drinks, which seems a little high, but hey, it's SF, what are you gonna do?

Cash only here.
author: Corinne L.

description:
Just don't come here when the feminist bartender is here and you have to hold your tongue (hard to drink and have fun that way). Also, Anchor Steam is $6.
Otherwise, great place.
author: Mag N.

description: A really super cute place for a quick drink. A quirky dive bar in the city - a great place to bring friends and visitors. Will be back.
author: Fi M.

description:
I've been coming here for nearly two decades.  Specs has always been a safe haven for locals like me.  Specs has been the spot for several great, memorable night's out with friends and family over the years.
...but tonight I was asked by the bartendress to "please quiet down" as other patrons were complaining that my table was too loud.  She actually shouted at me from behind the bar.  Several hours later, I am still stunned.
I apologized to said patrons on the way out.  They were nice enough, but WTF?
author: Deb Doran D.

description:
I mean, how cool is this old school place??!! 
Believe it or not, my pops frequented this dive back in the 60s and it was his favorite place. It's got character, but it has probably survived bc it's right off the main st. Edgier local crowd, but that makes it even cooler, right?
Don't forget the chess boards if you feel the urge. 
Personally, I stayed after the first beer bc the anchor steam is ridiculously smooth and creamy-- you won't find this east of the Mississippi. 
Cash only, novices.
author: Aaron S.

description:
40/50-somethings love this place! 

Specs has an older crowd and might not appreciate you and your rowdy group of young men coming in for a birthday - someone who looks like George Costanza asked the birthday boy to tone it tone. His crime: laughing. 

Aside from this element, drinking inside Specs feels like drinking inside a museum. Which is completely rad. You can really feel the history inside this bar. 

This is a very San Francisco experience, grumpy beatniks included. I know, guys - those young whipper snappers, I tell ya...
author: K M.

description:
Terrible attitude from the staff. Told us to be "more quite" we weren't making a scene. 
"Stop banging on the table"
author: Maria D.

description: A North Beach and SF institution.  Classic old style bar with lots of talking points on the walls, the ceiling and in the bar..  It is not a dive bar, if you think that you probably have never been in a dive bar, but it is a living bar which is warm and fun to have a beer or two in.
author: Des D.

description:
Great gem in San Francisco. Wandered nj while waiting for our city guides tour. Has awesome ambiance and a good selection of beer, wine and spirits. 

Quintessential San Fran.  I'll be back.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
Yes, Yes, Yes. 

When I went to college, I one day got the idea that I wanted to find my school's treasure trove of artifacts. Surely, like in Indian Jones, they had a basement or attic somewhere on campus filled with pirate doubloons, ancient marble tablets and -- here's hoping -- the arc of the covenant!

I did find the school's trove and it was cool -- filled with mostly shards of classical societies' pottery -- but it was nothing like I'd hoped for.

Fast Forward 10 years and I stumble in Spec's Twelve Adler Museum and Cafe. Thank you Spec's for filling the gap. Your walls are a dense rainforest of the archane and obscure: Egyptian sarcophaguses, stuffed mongooses attacking stuffed cobras, and god-knows-what else you have makes you the bastard child of the British Museum, Ripleys' Believe-it-Or-Not. The Museum of Jurassic Technology and a plain-ol' fun bar.

The night we were there, an artist had taken over the back, presenting hundreds of napkin-artworks. I bought him a beer (he wanted a Foster's in a big can) and a few minutes later he surprised our table wtih a crude sketch of all of us.

++ points fo supposedly being a favorite bar of the Beats.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Creepy Cool! Awesome spot to eat stuff, drink stuff, and soak in that Voodoo spirit.
A stones throw away from your friendly neighborhood beat spots
author: Mo R.

description:
Closed the place out.  The bar tender was super fuckin' sweet and a nice to us, probably because we're so super fuckin' sweet and nice!
They have no parking lot.
author: Andy H.

description:
This is one of the best bars in San Francisco if you like the dark literary place that has a strange collection of art scattered about its weathered and vaguely nautically themed walls.  

They talk about the beat poets a lot in North Beach, but maybe the only bar in North Beach that the beats would've pounded some gin in, is Specs.  It's not a large place, but it's so nicely spread out that you feel alone, even when surrounded by people.  A great place to have deep conversations or romantic banter. 

The kind of bar that keeps San Francisco cool.
author: daniel f.

description:
Oh Specs how i miss you when you looked a little more dingy on the outside! I totally loved going to have some of the best martinis and cosmos (before they were cool) of my life. And cheap too! So many times have I been there and been so buzzed with glee that i didnt mind if the male friends of the group wanted to partake in the Broadway activities. 

Hell it was the first bar I took my sister to! I remember that night vividly. The bartender was some old sailor guy with one of those voice boxes. Plus he had a heavy hand. It was kind of rad. Too many fun times.

I must say, as i passed there a little bit ago its kinda bright outside at night now. Its almost like you aren't my dirty little secret! But i still love you specs! See you soon!
author: Amanda J.

description: Great place. Cheap drinks, a bit small. great view of the hood. Not much more to say! total place for locals!
author: Jeff B.

description:
A co-worker took a group of us here for after-work drinks. At first this venue appeared to be just another hole-in-the-wall, but after spending some time there, it was clear there was something more to this place. 

The patrons are interesting - like straight out of a storybook interesting. I swear I saw Jack Sprat (who could eat no fat) and his wife. And I may have seen the woman who lives in a shoe and the man who lives in a crooked house. And they are all friends. I seriously looked up a few times and thought I was onto something like perhaps I was in a scene of that show Once Upon A Time. And to add to it, the bar is dark and somewhat dingy but right outside the doorway was a stream of light that hit a beautiful rose tree just right. It was a sight to be seen. The contrast was magical. Perhaps it was Snow White's apple tree.

I was not particuarly interested in going here, but it turned out to be one of my favorite San Francisco memories.
author: Angel W.

description:
Gin & Tonics since 1968.

Second of three stops on a vintage North Beach bar crawl.

Located in an alley. Low ceilings immediately give the space a sense of intimacy and energy. Grab a rickety table. Grab a strong drink. Take in the various ephemera.

Grandma would be impressed. Heavy on the gin. Light on the tonic. Surrounding strangers could easily become friends. Or perhaps that was just the gin.

Pretty sure ephemera and drinks will be flowing for years to come.

- - - - - - - - - -

Stop one: http://www.yelp.com/biz/tosca-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:PYSOiaiSg9sT9dqMOYzYNA

Stop three: http://www.yelp.com/biz/vesuvio-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:AMuBFW_TCXckhN693baqNA
author: Jason B.

description:
This type of bar is one of the reasons why I think I officially like SF more than LA.

Charming, old, cool....

You still have those places in LA but you really gotta hunt for them. Here you can just stumble into any old place and find a gem.

This was a gem of a gem... An emerald if you will.

The beers were fine--$5 for a Stella. But you really go for the atmosphere. The old bricks. The beer stained wood. The antique furniture with old signs collected for a century. Not like new signs made to look old like in a Crackerbarrel or an Applebees in the Midwest...

Bathrooms were kind grimy though.
author: Bobby C.

description:
North Beach has a smattering of viable boozer bars for the career drinker. Lower North Beach proves to hold a few of such places and none more quirky and engaging then Specs. 

Walking up Columbus you can miss it peeking out from inside a teeny alleyway. Walk into the bar and you see the narrow wooden wonder of Specs....faded, kitschy posters, photos and signs of all kinds line the walls. 

Order up a 'Cheese Plate' and a beer and just sit back with friends and revel in the amazing weirdness and fabulous oddity of Specs. 

P.S. Get a portrait done for $5 if the artist is sitting in the back table.
author: Jay H.

description: Cool, laid back institution. Great little beatnik dive bar in north beach.  Off the beaten path from the tourist spots.  Everyone there was relaxed and enjoying themselves.  The staff was friendly.  Drinks are reasonably priced.
author: Greta R.

description:
This is the choice beatnick-atmosphere, hole-in-the-wall-(of an alley) type of bar, that's not dirty and includes a piano. You may find some old timers jamming here, which is becoming increasingly more rare in this world.

Good price... drinks/service are all great.
author: David D.

description: This is something out of the ordinary. All the objects coated with dust. Stickers lining the inside of the bar. All sorts of people frequenting this place. Great place to hang out for a drink. Recommended that you check out their bins of postcards all talking about the American Dream. Not sure why that's the theme, but they are very interesting nonetheless. Completely recommended if you're wandering around North Beach.
author: N. M.

description:
Never empty, but I've never been here when it was too full either. Weird decorations and clientele. Seriously, you'll see some strange characters in here, and you'll probably see a homeless person fall asleep at some point. 

A must if you frequent North Beach.

Fifth star would be if they cleaned it up just a little and accepted cards (cash only).
author: Jason M.

description: Cute place, sure. But nothing excuses lousy service when there is literally 8 people in your bar at 5pm. The Guinness tasted a bit off and a little light too...maybe the taps need some cleaning?
author: A S.

description: Your first reaction to this place is going to be that it's slightly creepy, and you'd be totally right. It's a little more than slightly creepy, but the bartender's pretty nice, and the drinks aren't too expensive. It's a real dive, though, and the clientele leaves much to be desired. Someone puked on the floor the Friday night I was there. That was pretty hilarious.
author: Danny C.

description: Great local bar. Good draft selection including anchor steam, stella, and Guinness. Dos Equis, Heineken, rainier, Olympia, Budweiser, and Victoria bottles available too. No lock on the women's restroom stall! Great music and so many items on the walls to look at. It never gets old. I particularly like the sign about a "convenient regulation size alleyway for the settling of physical contests".
author: Joy C.

description: Love the atmosphere and I've had really friendly service from the bar tender. Will definitely come back here for an after hour drawing session!
author: Breena N.

description: This bar has the best vibe for tarot readings. They also have the best bar snack basket in North Beach, not to mention super cheap cans of Olympia and "Vitamin R". Spec's rules.
author: Kelly O.

description: This place is tucked away in a corner right across the street from City Lights bookstore and Vesuvio bar. Chill dark bar with lots cool looking items on the walls. They have a small but decent selection of beers on tap and some cheap rainier in a can if you don't want to spend alot. My brother ordered an irish coffee which was surprisingly good. I had an anchor steam and a fernet. The bartender is very friendly and knowledgeable about all kinds of things, especially music and knows exactly when to ask if your ready for another drink without being pushy or making you have to flag him down. Great place to have a fernet, some cheese from the wheel, and just kick back while chatting with some locals.
author: Robin H.

description:
A great dive tucked away in the world's shortest alley in North Beach. There's usually some odd thing happening just outside the door. Someone might be playing the piano inside. Lots of old things, and that includes the clientele. ; ) It's a place typically shunned by douchey frat types and the douchey women they chase. Sweet! You can get cheese and crackers if you're feeling peckish.

Cash only.
author: Diana O.

description: The best of the bars in San Francisco. Cheap drinks, basket of cheese and crackers, old beat poets drinking with you, folk music and the boxes of postcard. Humble and real.
author: Shannon Z.

description: Wonderful divey bar. Lots of wood and artifacts. Not touristy. Not as inexpensive as it should be but it is so centrally located and you pay for the atmosphere.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Great location, very cool objects and paintings but.....$6 for a pint with 2 inches of foam and no happy hour is not my kinda dive. Tourist trap even for locals.
author: B. L.

description:
I don't know how to feel about this place.

On the one hand, it's in North Beach. And in that pocket of North Beach where bars are everywhere.

On the other hand, the strangest people tend to show up and there's a large crab hanging on the wall.

It's not a pretentious place. And a friend of mine once got into a quasi-lightsaber battle with a street vendor right outside the door, while his girlfriend was a mere foot away getting hit on by someone who looked like a cross between Amy Winehouse and Danny DeVito. Hmmm... considering that, yeah, this place is pretty cool.
author: J. S.

description:
This is a dive bar that charges $14 for two drinks.  This makes me think it's a perfect museum of a dive bar. One that doesn't exist anymore.  And people want a real dive bar so badly that they'll pay $14 for two drinks in order to pretend they are in one.

If you want to pretend you are in a dive bar, this place is absolutely cool.  I honestly loved it.
author: NoCal S.

description:
A hidden gem in San Francisco's North Beach close to a corner of Broadway & Columbus.

Spec's rocks an old school look with an old school vibe.  It's where I like to go to change things up from the all too familiar North Beach crowd.  Spec's is rather small and cramp, especially when busy, but I'd rather be here than some stuck up scene in North Beach.  The prices for their libations are considerably less than other places in the area also.

Someone is usually playing the piano here at night.  I don't know if he works there or not but he does accept tips.  I usually shoot him a few if I like the tunes he plays.  Unfortunately, he doesn't know the classic jazz tune "All Of Me"...I love that piece.
author: Jules S.

description:
This bar is really, really cool.  It's tucked away in a little North Beach alley and is very dark and cozy, all of which make it perfect for a daytime drink!

Add to that its eclectic decor, which includes lots of bizarre antiques, and you have the impression of entered a really cool, secret place right out of a movie.  

The only downside is that, like any and all North Beach bars, in the evenings and weekends, this place gets pretty crowded, which does kill the spooky off the beaten path vibe.
author: Dave S.

description: The history of the place is definitely cool, it was huge during the beatnik movement, but the drinks are ridiculously over priced. I much prefer vesuvio across the street, just as much history but better bar.
author: Grace P.

description:
Specs' is a freaking money spot. It's kinda hidden in the corner of an alley, but if you find it, you will enjoy it for sure. It's definitely a dive bar with a pretty chill atmosphere, but the bartenders and selection of beer definitely make it different than your average San Fran hole in the wall bar. 

Oh yeah...if you want, the bartender will give you cheese and crackers. And by cheese, I don't mean that garbage Kraft singles stuff, I'm talking good sharp cheddar with saltine crackers. Which is slamming, especially with a nice cold beer. If you're looking to just get some brews and kick it in an old school pub, Specs' is your spot. Boom...with cheese and saltine crackers on top!
author: Aaron N.

description:
Love this place. Reminds me of some of your finer Alaskan establishments minus the sawdust but with the same male/female ratio (ladies- the odds are good, but the goods are odd). 
If you're taking your cool/old school-loving friends and family members on a tour of SF, this is a must stop. Gives you instant SF tour guide street cred.
author: Johanna S.

description: Clearly one of the only appropriate relics left in this city. This is a very local bar, but always open to outsiders and tourists. I'm pretty sure that the majority of the negative reviews on this place were written by douche bags.
author: J. G.

description:
My first impressions: a hangout for North Beach locals and aging hippies, lots of "stuff" plastered on the walls must be some sort of historical shit, popular considering it's a Sunday night

I was here for one night to have a couple of beers with friends, enjoy good conversation and to view some short films.  That's right.  I went to Specs to watch a movie.

My friend Gregg M seems to be a regular customer here.  He starred in the twelve minute flick titled "Jake and Ronne" which maybe not so coincidentally was filmed in its entirety at Specs.  The film was directed by another friend, Mark N, who doesn't seem to be a regular here.  Anyway, good stuff.  In part because the bar patrons were lively and made a lot of noise while cheering on familiar shots or cameos by the bartender made this a very enjoyable evening.

They have Sierra Nevada on tap so I was happy.  Cool bartenders and loud music played softly so one can actually enjoy good conversation without shouting.

Two of my first impressions turned out to be right.  The crowd is a good mix of friendly North Beach locals and modern day hippies, and maybe because of film night this was a very popular place on a Sunday evening.

The stuff on the wall wasn't very historical unless you consider how old they are.  Vintage signs and famous quotes mostly with an assortment of knick-knacks here and there.  There's some really hilarious graffiti in the restroom too.  Ah, local charm.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I pretty much love everything about this bar and try to come here whenever I am in the neighborhood. I always get a dirty vodka martini.$5, best deal in the city!!

The cheese and crackers is also amazing. The slice you off a chunk from a giant cheese wheel and the bar and give you a sleeve of saltines. Love that. 

Fun characters here as well, %50 percent of the time I come here there is at least one person with a bird on their shoulder! haha. 

Remember, cash only.
author: Claire b.

description:
Stay classy, guys. I couldn't actually order a drink because I had to drive shortly after arriving, but I liked the ambiance and the "old timer" feeling of the place. The piano player added a great touch, and the all-wooden bar made me feel like I was in some sort of British pub. Good, large tables for groups, and manageable noise levels.

Also, there's this really cool artist guy who sort of sits along the side of the place near the bar and makes creations while you watch.
author: Andrew L.

description:
How can a local saloon merit a five-star rating despite the following facts? :  The place hasn't changed its interior decoration in thirty years. It's often overrun with the seventy-something equivalent of Williamsburg hipsters in aging, salty, faux-communists and self-consciously declared 'artist' types. Even if you've been going here for thirty years you're still likely to be looked upon as a clueless newcomer subtracting from the joint's authenticity. If you have been going here for a while you're likely to sit next to some thirty year-old blowhard who discovered the place three weeks ago and is waxing philosophic to the young, uneasy-looking cheeserettes next to him on the bar's 'history', Specs' merchant marine connection, and the phallic whale bone on the wall (all things you could easily pick up in one drunken visit.)

Because none of this matters. To both its absolute credit and demise, Specs never changes and as long as the man himself is making the rounds in North Beach and signing the rent checks this will remain a fact. He's loyal to his bartenders and they to him, coming back to the place after extended hiatuses. They make a mean Irish coffee (only having boosted the price a buck recently) using the same archaic blender to gently stir the cream since 1971. When they bumped the draft taps up from only Bud to Anchor and eventually a few more it remained the central topic of conversation regarding how the place had 'changed' for about fifteen years. It provides an excellent counter to Vesuvio across the street and general refuge from the touristy onslaught. It's also a great counter to the Tosca vibe next door and a drunken respite from Sean Penn-seekers and less-homey 'don't put your feet up on the furniture' admonishments. 

Specs is what it is, and that it's remained so for almost forty-five years is one of those inspiring facts that one can only cling to with apprehension. The man himself is a salty pleasure, neither kissing up to patrons nor dismissing them, and over the years seems to have taken his real pleasure from mixing it up with both regulars and newcomers (none more than attractive young females) who are generally delighted to discover that he owns the place. But anyone who's been around the joint for a while has to wonder what will become of things post The Man? It doesn't seem possible that the next generation could maintain as he has for this long and one hopes there's a solid succession plan in place complete with detailed instruction book. Of the three (Vesuvios, Specs and Tosca) if you had to pick one whose removal or upheaval would permanently alter an important link to North Beach's past, it would be this place. Make all the Beat arguments and celebrity-refuge points you want, Specs *is* North Beach.
author: R M.

description: Great place to stop in and grab a beer. Nice bartender, who most importantly knows the difference between good Guinness and great Guinness.
author: Glenn M.

description:
Cool little neighborhood bar with a lot of history. Good beers on tap - lights, darks ambers etc..
It seemed like there were a lot of locals there just trying to have a good time. It wasn't like they typical bar where everyone is trying hard to hook up with someone.
author: Rich P.

description: This is some old sckool San Francisco for sure. Keep the place clean, the regulars will be grateful.
author: David S.

description:
Specs has character...Specs has history....Specs has SOUL.  The fact that it's North Beach location subjects it to a horde of tourists on the weekends might detract from this somewhat, but doesn't diminish it completely.

What you see inside is a more than just a snapshot from a single period or culture.  Browsing the walls and ceilings exposes one to a broad swath of San Francisco history that changes it's gist and period with every movement of the eye.  There's stuff from the 70's that boomers can relate to.  There are relics from the 60's that ex-hippies can appreciate.  There's city-specific history from World War II that your parents might have fond memories of.  Check out the old artifacts from the Sutro baths, and you'll see things that might even give your grandparents the warm-and-fuzzies.

Even though a similar collection of artifacts could no doubt be amassed, it's haphazard assembly and mishmash arrangement weave a bizarre quilt of history whose evolution over a period of 40 or more years can't be faked.  Everywhere you look, there are pictures, papers, scribblings....some framed, some not. Some are tacked to the walls at the corners, displaying a gradual yellowing that only age can bring about and a soft curvature that's only created by decades of gentle gravitational pull.  It seems that more recent placements of items have had respect for what was existed there before, creating a delightful asymmetry that bears more witness to history than it does decorative talent.

If you're around during the weekend, pop by mid-afternoon when a smattering of the old guard locals will chat politics for hours on end.  The after-work crowd can be pretty interesting too.  Late mornings and early afternoons are hit-and-miss....sometimes it's open, sometimes it's not. Weekend nights usually draw a crowd....the tourists come in, the music goes up, and it doesn't take long for the regulars to head for the door.  Regardless, pop by to get an eye full of history...stick around for awhile if you can squeeze your way into a conversation with a group of the regulars.  But have a plan B if the tourists are about. The decor is worth a visit, but it's nothing that'll keep you entertained all night...
author: Mike W.

description:
A true piece of San Francisco. A nice break from the over the top atmosphere of North Beach. Eclectic doesn't even begin to describe the decor - nautical I've heard? If I were you, I would order beer here. Plunk down a few bucks, and you can get a plate of cheese and crackers - informal munchies. As stated in other reviews, cash only - I think I still owe them a buck actually.

Oh yeah, look out for friendly folks dubbed "FOS" - friends of Specs. They help the bartenders clean tables. Gotta love it.
author: Jon L.

description: What a fun little dive bar.  I was only in SF for a day and a local brought me to Specs for a after work beer, it definitely had a lot of character and I was happy to experience an off the beaten path establishment.  I can't speak much to the quality of drinks or service, but I would love to return here if I'm ever in town again and see if it lives up to all these great reviews!
author: Caroline B.

description:
Quiet place for an after work drink. Nice people, great bartenders, Made NYTimes list of top ten bars in SF, although they said it was full of weirdos. I can assure you, I am there almost every day and I've never noticed any weirdos.

After about seven or eight it fills up with creepy young people and becomes a 'dive bar'.
author: Fled F.

description: Eccentric dive bar hidden away in North Beach. Walked past all the time and never knew this was here. Best part is the huge chunk of cheese and saltine crackers you can get as a snack.
author: Kelly R.

description:
This is the epitome of a bar for me. There's no t.v. and the music playing is definitely not top 40. A curious mixture of div, irish pub and museum, Specs feels like home. Sunday afternoons have made Specs into "Church" for us--- the hunk of fontina cheese and crackers our wafers, a Brandy Alexander the wine, and the greatest preachers, I mean, bartenders I've had the pleasure of serving me. I went away for a few weeks and went in to order my drink and they knew me immediately, just from a drink.
Best. Place. Ever.
author: Vee B.

description: Laura is awesome!  Great drinks, cool vibe but bring cash!  They don't take credit cards.
author: Yvette Marlene P.

description:
If you love dive bars and nautical paraphernalia  (and really, who doesn't?) than you are going to LOVE Specs'. It's the hidden gem of North Beach and the place I escape to on the weekends when my regular bar, Vesuvio, is chocked full of the Bridge and Tunnel crowd. 

The wine is awful (about a half step up from drinking turpentine) but the bartenders and the charm of the space more than make up for it. Be warned that Specs' is cash only.
author: Angela M.

description: I don't know if i came at the wrong time or on the wrong night but i just wasn't feelin' Adler's Museum Cafe. It was somewhat empty and a bit musky feeling. I almost walked into a man with a Dumbledore beard and i felt he resembled a pirate with a peg leg. I'm sure the nautical vibe is to blame a bit but we only stopped in for a while before we continued our bar hopping.
author: Samantha L.

description: I dig this place. Its funky, its somewhat of a dive, and not many people know about it. It reeks with nostalgia, with walls covered in old photo & weird collectors items and because of its odd location, mostly locals know about it. Its not fancy by a long shot. But its cool, off the beaten path, and the drinks are cheap & strong.
author: Jen S.

description: Unusual pictures and items from all over the world posted on the walls and hanging from the ceiling, definitely will get conversation going. Intimate casual atmosphere. Good cheap drinks, friendly bartender. Good bar for people watching, mixed crowd. This place has a lot of character and old San Francisco charm. Across from Vesuvios Café, another bar that will take you back in time to a different San Francisco.
author: Ron W.

description: Old school bar, old school service, old school tunes. Tick, tick and tick, as those boxes go. Don't come here expecting frills, but do come with an open mind and you won't leave disappointed. A veritable blast from the past. Two thumbs up!
author: T K.

description:
Screw the stuff on the walls.
I have never noticed anyone in here looking "touristy".
Perhaps there are tourists, but thankfully they are not American ones.

This is a bar.
Just a bar.

And that is a rare thing to find in a bar these days.
It's comfortable, but thankfully not too comfortable.

There is no pretense.  There is no line.
When I go, there is always plenty of seating.
It's not too loud.  There is no TV.
And after a few, the cheese guillotine really hits the spot.

All good things.
author: Daniel B.

description:
For some reason, I love a bar with history....history literally plastered on every open space on the walls is even better! Not that my boyfriend and I lack any conversation, but this place lends to our topics! It's wall to every crack in the wall stuff that really is super amazingly interesting! 

Besides being a place with a ton of history, the bartender and patrons are actually very accommodating and friendly. They notice when you take a seat and clean up very quickly after each patron. 

My boyfriend and I enjoyed a drink and looked a some stuff on the walls leaving some to come back later and discover. Had a wonderful time here and can't make the rounds again!
author: Karen C.

description:
Any place with a spectacle-clad old irish bartender is alright with me! I have a great time at specs each time I go, I don't know too many people who've even heard of it so if I want to chill and have a few drinks with friends in a really low-key setting I go here. No music, no frills just a lot of cool signs on the walls and old school flare. My favorite are the baskets of postcards from all over the world, they don't put them out when it's busy so you have to ask. The best are the ones from a gentleman searching for the "american dream" and there is one from nearly every state!
"I thought i'd find it on the Jersey shore. I was wrong."
author: Nikki M.

description:
Random good times, that is what you'll get from having a night at Specs. This is probably one of my favorite dive bars ever. But it doesn't seem right to call it a dive. Maybe because of all stuff on the walls and the fact that it feels like an old joint my Grandfather would love either way it's brilliant.

It's not pretentious, it's easy going and a place for locals or those just trying to get away from that shiteous club scene. You'll definitely find a diverse crowd and probably start chatting up with people that have been frequenting this place "since before you were a thought in your daddy's eyes" that man was too sweet, and there was NO way I was going home with him, but still sweet. This is a bar where I feel comfortable coming with a big group of friends or a place where I just want to have a few drinks on my own and kick back and enjoy the atmosphere.

Big Pros: CHEAP DRINKS and good conversations
author: Morgan M.

description: Stiff drinks, along with the peculiarities of it's name, the dim lighting and worn wood interiors, this bar is indeed a museum. I could drink and explore this place with a magnifying glass for years and never get bored. Friendly bartenders and an eclectic group of patrons, easily one of the most interesting bars in San Francisco.
author: Clarke W.

description: Cool dive bar good for groups.  Some drunk newbs were playing chess in the corner.  I thought they were going to start a bar fight over a game of chess.  Damn wannabe n3rds.
author: Fatty A.

description: Had a lot of awesome nights here, it would take way too long to write about the incredibly interesting adventures I had but definitely some of the best nights of my life started here. Whenever I'm in San Francisco I go back and see the same people. Bar tenders have always been nice.
author: Josh L.

description:
Aw... Specs is the first bar I patroned in San Francisco. I was an eager, young transfer student when I moved to San Francisco State. Random computer pairing roomed me with three AWESOME roommates and a floor full of neighbors who were all a few years older than me. I would listen to them talk about the fun bars and clubs they went to the night before and I remembered how much I wanted flex my newfound freedom and join in on the drunken good times. They would invite me, of course, but it really sucked to have to say, "I can't go... I'm still 20..." Only parties for me. Sad face. 

Then one night, someone said the magical words, "We're going to Specs - they might not check." I couldn't have gone to a better first bar. I loved everything about it, from the decor to the people to the atmosphere. The drinks aren't super fancy (I think the first thing someone stuck in my had after I sat down was a SoCo and Coke) and that's the way it should be. It's a great place to chillax because, honestly, noone gives a crap. Specs is just a place you go to enjoy some drinks, enjoy some convo, and enjoy some friends.
author: Queenie C.

description: So... we can never remember the name or the exact location of this place, but surely enough we end up stumbling down Columbus near the end of a long night, looking for this spot.  Perfect place for a night cap (or few) after dinner.   I don't remember the beer selection being very large, but I can always find something I'm happy to drink.  Tables in the back are great for small groups.
author: Heidi M.

description: I'm sitting at the bar, it's fourth of July and I've watched the glowing fireworks through the SF fog. Specs is as random as it can get. Hole in the wall history in the heart of north beach. Slice of cheese and a drink please!
author: TVAT T.

description:
I feel another numbered review coming on! Here are two reasons why I like Specs'. (I thought it was Spec's, but you know, I trust Yelp. I also have high apostrohe misuse fear, which is why I mention it.)

1. They have a big cheese wheel. Yes, a big wheel of nice cheese, and what goes better with cheese than beer? They have beer, too.

2. I purchased cheese with crackers and two beers for $15. Is that a deal, or what?

I also happen to like Specs'  because I met my specialfriendlifepartnerboyfriendbuddy there a couple of years ago after a Christmas party. Well, it was a work Christmas party. Close by. So I shouldn't maybe give that one to Specs', but I'm going to anyway. But no number.
author: Leata H.

description:
Do not pass up a chance to go here. Have a shot, watch people doing their thing. This is as good as it gets.

Also: Would be a great place for hatching a conspiracy. Just sayin'.
author: Mark S. I.

description: It really is like a museum in here. And it's cozy. And it's divey. And they have Anchor Steam on tap (4 glasses = 1 pitcher, fyi). And I like it.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Wild salmon don't do drugs.  Specs' is a cool little place to hang out at, especially as a non-local seeking non-touristy places to visit.  The crowd was friendly and plenty of beers were on tap to choose from.  The bartender had a delightfully surly sense of humor; the legendary cheese plate was the only thing missing from my personal experience.
author: Scott V.

description:
This funky bar is always interesting. strange older people, beatnick types, musicians. Awsome place covered in history and wildness. 

Stay away if you are looking for a young scene or a real crazy night. Its just awsome to dig the scene and hang out with friends. The opposite of nearby Kell's.

Combine with Vesuvios and The Saloon for a historical and zany bar crawl.
author: James B.

description: We must've stumbled into this bar during the drunken homeless hour (12:00 AM on a Thursday). I love a good dive bar and based upon previous Yelp reviews this one was supposed to be quite the "gem".  I think we caught it on a bad night as there were two drunks (man & woman) who were either homeless or from a shelter. Yes the bar had plenty of potential but I think we'd of been better off checking it out earlier in the evening. Most people ignored the drunks even when they would stumble upon them and bombard their conversations. The regulars or perhaps City dwellers were used of this occurrence and simply ignored them as much as possible. The bartenders were nice and definitely quick with the drinks but lacked crowd control pertaining to the two drunks. I hate knocking the place because it definitely could've been a cool place had those drunks not ruined the comfort level for the two of us from out of town.
author: Sonny H.

description:
LOVED IT!! for the following reasons:

1- theres so much stuff on the walls and in cases i could spend days there!! the bartender, while a little weird, would point out cool things and explain about others. i feel like you would have to work there for a long time to see it all. AWESOME!!

2- they have games. if you are a bar and have darts/ games. i love you. why people [ my bf] wont play [with me] i dunno, but i love it. ill play and i dont care who's laughing. 

3- the drinks were good and strong. the bartender wouldnt make us a car bomb. and after i asked, wouldnt even sell me a beer and a shot. i guess i understand why, not wanting a belligerent crowd and youngsters. i just prefer to get the alcohol in me as fast as possible bc i tend to babysit my drinks.

4- there were some characters outside!! omg!! this is def a must if you are in north beach!!!
author: Delaney P.

description: Some older guy that appeared to be running the placed was not too kind and told 20 of us to leave on a weeknight.  Apparently you can't just overwhelm the place when locals are there and want it quiet.  1 star for not letting us patronize.
author: Simon Y.

description: Welcome to Specs.  Second stop on my traditional walkabout in North Beach/T-Hill.   Cheers Specs Simmons!  Trippy weird place in half an alley across from the first stop, Vesuvio and third stop and alleymate,  the Tosca Cafe.  This is my favorite of the three.  Must visit even if you don't stay for the cheese plate, beer and people watching.  Some old guy stole my drink!  8th or 9th time in there over the last 4 years and I swear the place looks EXACTY the same.  Be forewarned, do not order a stupid foo foo drink here.
author: Paul J.

description:
Oh Specs.  I've had some fun there.  Many people have.  The place is well traveled.
And often filled with odd and colorful people.
I remember back when they didn't have tap beers.  Oh, the 90's.
Hungry?  Get a slice of cheese from that massive block with a handful of saltines.
Sure, the place will be full of loud drunk people.
And crazy people will be hanging around outside the place where people are smoking.
Join 'em.
Live a little.
author: Kev M.

description: This place has a uniqueness to it that is very hard to describe. It's got's a very diverse crowd of customers, a very odd feel to it. The decor is in a category of it's own. Very out there. I'm not really sure how else to describe it but quaint. Definitely worth checking out. You'll meet some interesting people!
author: Michael N.

description:
Best bar in North Beach. 
This place has cheese and beer! Like sharp cheese. 
The decorum looks like some mariner's version of Buco di Beppo like a cross between a souvenir shop and an Elks lodge. There is always someone there that looks like they've been going there since the gold rush. 
But what its got is no specific scene and that makes it magical. 
And after your done drinking and conversing its not far to go find some warm easy meat. *wink wink nudge nudge*
author: Rocker D.

description:
Best place in North Beach to feel like you're not in North Beach. Drinks are small and overpriced, but the ambiance is worth it. If you're loud, obnoxious, and otherwise North Beach-y (i.e. the type of asshat who pounds on your table and screams for more jagabombs jagabombs jagabombs), don't bother. There are countless bars and clubs in NB that just LOVE to pack themselves to the popped collar with Marina, and B&T DBs just like you, so please leave Specs' to those of us wanting to have a beverage and a civilized conversation at an off the beaten path watering hole.

Minus one star for the aforementioned social dingleberries, and another for the short pours and tall prices.
author: Samir O.

description:
I'm not usually a fan of "dive bars", but Specs is an exception.  A very cool atmosphere.  Not a place to party, but a great place for a small gathering to have a few beers.  The crowd is always cool, friendly, and diverse.
It is one of those hidden San Francisco gems, and everyone should have a chance to experience.
author: B J.

description:
MISSED CONNECTIONS

Reply to: AZNdbzFAN@asianavenue.com
Date: 2007-11-11, 10:24AM PST

Possibly South American artsy girl on 11/3 - m4w - 25

You saw me looking at you... My friend asked you for a light... We both like your shoes... Overuse of ellipses... 

One must review Spec's in relation to its surroundings. This is North Beach, the Vegas of SF. In one short walkthrough, I can easily collect about five strip club cards, and talk to at least two strippers (gosh, they sure seemed smart). Spec's is a cozy writers' bar with $4 beers on tap, good looking people and plenty of space. While it may not be my first choice for a hangout in the city, it certainly shines within this district. But alas, while I write, I am not a writer, and thus I find myself at ends with impressing such types.

I will bee back tonight okay... If you see an Asian guy nursing a cosmo thats me... come say high and mention CL... we can begin a normal converstation from there...
author: Keane L.

description:
This place used to be known for it's wildlife, I.e. roaches, but it seems like they've got control of the insect population.

I'd rather be here than Vesuvio but neither would be my first choice.
author: Manny F.

description:
Ok. I'm 5'8, Curvy, Athletic and well...Substantial.  So, I'm comfortable patronizing Specs on any late night.  You can have a stiff drink alone at one of the round tables -or- enjoy congenial conversation with the bar keep and the regulars.  I love variety!  

But, you cannot find yourself behind the Alley of Mr. Bings across the way because your ass will get mugged!  Unless you are me (here's where I praise myself in the third person).  

Nadja lives a dark dangerous life where hard drinking and objectifying men  play a large part.  Here is her story:

"After a late drink at Spec's I found myself surrounded by at least a dozen surly, hungry-eyed potential attackers.  

Clever banter ensued.  Bravado met bravada.  Ultimately they knew my chic taupe macrame' hand bag (homage to 70's vintage) was not goin' down without a fight.  

I take my Wing Chun stance and make Michelle Yeoh proud.  With all the cockiness of Bruce in "Game of Death" I instigate a little "Play".  I toy with my prey then bring about the final unforgiving blows.  Alerting my would-be attackers, in a Black Mamba way that they are free to go...but, their limbs are mine!"

Spec's is great!  Take caution in the surrounding areas. 
You can't all be Kung-Fu masters like me!
author: R M.

description:
Pretty cool wax museum... They serve beer to the figures and on weeknights the homeless tell jokes outside in the alley-like ambience.  
If your alley-hoppin' and need a place that doesn't care if you take your drink outside so you can smoke out with Foot Stompin' Fred before wandering on... this is your place for the night.
author: Kenny R.

description:
Specs!!  I know thee well.  I first heard about this bar via Adam Adler RIP. He was the gayest(good) guy at Abraham Lincoln HS. I don't think he is any relation to the street name.  I remember how excited he was to know there was a bar and street named after him.  This was in 1982.

Since 1968, Specs Twelve Adler Museum Cafe -- Specs to you -- has thrived as a North Beach holy spot

It was a sad day in Specs' history when the door connecting the bar to the upstairs strip club was closed off, corking the stream of scantily clad women who ventured down. The bartender, patrons and owner of the North Beach saloon dealt with the convulsive change in a traditional way: They had a drink.

The bar, which is formally called Specs Twelve Adler Museum Cafe and was opened in 1968 in an alley off Columbus Avenue in San Francisco, has been home to a menagerie of misfits, from strippers and poets to longshoremen and merchant marines. A sign reading, "Please mind your head'' hangs above the bar next to the genitalia of a walrus. A photo of Ronald Reagan stretching his legs includes the homemade caption, "One of these days these boots are gonna walk all over you."

The bar is a slice of a bawdier San Francisco, a foil for the modern day Internet cafe, a dimly lit place that inspires conversation, debate and impromptu poetry readings. 

I remeber the Handwriting Lady. I remember passing out after drinking Kama-Kazi's on a school night.  Kathy Gray now a cop threw up in Clown Alley's Bathroom.  Some dude paid for a cab/taxi ride from North Beach to my house...  That is a $40.00 cab ride folks.

I still drop in to Specs when I am down that way. I love it when I run into the owner. He is such a character.

This space has a deeper history...in the 40's it was a secret/underground Gay and Lesbian Bar.  

God I love this town. I always leave my heart in San Francisco.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
Having a bunch of sorta historical looking junk all over the walls does not a museum make. Museums have their historical looking junk laid out in a coherent way, and they have information about the junk and guided tours and they sell memberships and you're not allowed to touch anything. And I've never seen a museum with restrooms as bizarre and foul smelling as these. 

But none of the other museums I've been to recently have such capable bartenders and reasonably priced drinks and odd but refreshingly down to earth patrons. Spec's is not at all like other north beach bars; There's no neon, no dance music blasting, no gelled hair inside. It's tucked away in a little alley off of Columbus with a tiny sign. You won't find it if you're not looking for it. 

This place may very well have inspired Billy Joel to write 'Pianoman' (there was a live piano player last time I was there!) At least a third of the regulars could have been Davy who's still in the Navy and there were a fair number more who evidently never had time for a wife. They're all generally friendly though.

Stop in here if you're tired of crowds and noise and stuck on Columbus. Spec's is there for you.
author: matthew r.

description:
It's dark, musty, and there's an old piano that harkens back to a jazzy era. Ancient postcards sit at the bar, ready to be pawed through. The regular patrons fit the scene, with a Cafe Trieste/City Lights ancient beatnik vibe. There's pride and history in this North Beach dive, and I totally dig it.

And I'm not trying to be a square, man, but when the younger generational folk come into the bar for a drink, there's some elitism occurring here. On a random weekday night I came in with some friends and we sat at a table, sharing stories and enjoying each other's company. That is until we were sent a message by the bartender. We were told to keep it down, and our voices at their best, "indoor volume," (imagine you're in a library). And as my friends and I continued to converse at our table, constantly shushing each other and casting furtive glances around the fully-occupied bar, we realized it just wasn't worth our time, so we split.

Also another word to the young folk, take caution when approaching and departing, because outside the entrance of bar lurks a bit of ragamuffin riff-raff. No seriously, my sister was randomly clocked my a homeless guy here once.

I respect that Spec's has it's own protocol's, but cool it big daddy.
author: Sonya Y.

description:
I've been in there twice, and both times the bartender has been cranky.  Our group was 15+ and bought a lot of beer.  She said to quiet down because, "there are a lot of old people with hangovers in here", and then asked us to leave.  We were the bulk of her business that night and she was really rude to a large group of customers throwing money her way.  If you're an old timer staggering and slurring, it's the perfect place for you to take a nap.

UPDATE! Just wanted to share a personal email I received yesterday from Vern F. upon reviewing Specs:

"Ever think that perhaps it was you and your party who were "rude", and not the bartender who was simply doing her job by trying to keep the atmosphere the way Specs himself wants it to be?

No, of course you wouldn't think that, because clearly you're nothing more than Daddy's little princess who thinks that spending money entitles a person to act like a complete and utter dipshit, with no repercussions whatsoever.

Stick to the Marina bars where they put up with your type of nonsense, and leave Specs to those of us who know how to behave in a fucking bar."

Your pal,
Vern
author: Katie M.

description:
This place looks like someone  went on a $50000 shopping spree at Paxton Gate,  and threw all of it on the walls. I know that's not what happened, this place came first, but still, I like the idea of someone doing that. I also love how it's shoe horned in to a little alleyway. 

Here is how it could turn into a 5 star establishment: Racer 5 on tap.

This review sucks, read Adrienne G's and Andy F's for more fun.
author: neil c.

description:
The bartenders at Spec's are assholes. The primary clientele could be described as "interesting" if you're looking in the door, but if you actually go in and hang out with them, you'll find out it's more like going to a bar full of the very same crazy homeless people you cross the street to avoid when you're downtown.

I remember not minding Spec's the first time I went in there. The decorations are cool and, as I said, the patrons aren't immediately alienating. Also, we just went in there and drank.

The next time I went, it was for a friend's moving-away celebration. We sat in the back, it was fucking noisy, and the bartender mistook us for some other people. Then several of us started messing around with this little rubber flogger thing that we'd picked up earlier in the day, just, like, hitting each other with it. Nothing sexual, just goofing around. We were told by the bartender that it wasn't "that kind of bar" and had to stop.

Then a little later one of us started singing an old sea shanty. He was also told that it wasn't "that kind of bar" and when I asked the bartender why they had a piano if they weren't the kind of bar where you could make music, he responded with, "Sorry, house rules."

I've never been back. If you want the kind of bar where you're supposed to sit silently next to some stinky toothless old fucker mumbling into his dirty beer glass, drowning your sorrows over also being a smelly geriatric transient, then my rating for you would be 5 stars instead of one.
author: Lynae Z.

description:
I used to go to Spec's with my fake ID in the early 90s. Since then, it has always held a place in my heart. There are many stories and storytellers there. Like the man who used to bring his pet bunny into the bar and if you bought him a beer,  you could hold the bunny.

and did you know that on Sundays from noon to 4, they host a life drawing class? costs money, but good for you artists.

and the cheesewheel. how can anyone not like this place? its gets crowded on weekends, but for some reason, i can tolerate it, which is rare for me.

the other day i was there with my friend Kevin. within minutes we were helping tourists out with their map. i think it just brings out the best in people. 

don't go to Tosca. go to Spec's. then again, don't go, because I want Spec's all to myself.
author: Olivia W.

description:
Bring some cash or smile at your friends with cash so they buy you drinks because Specs is cash only. 
That being said, it's well worth it. Nice brownish gold color, hole in the wall pretty much literally, piano in back, guy who drifts in to play and let me tell you thank God is or at least the night I was there no comparison to crappy Billy Joel. There was a little barrel house and some stride going on. 
Nets on the wall, things to read. I was staring at Jack London all night. 
Some other pics. 
Crawled over here after a day at Kennedy's, House of Nan King, Vesuvio across the street and ended up here at the suggestion of a friend. Thanks friend.
Crowd was cool and kept to themselves, unless you felt like mingling. Not a pick up joint. 
Nice stiff drinky and good beers. Interested in hitting it back up for the cheese.
author: malibulala B.

description:
There was a piano player rocking the solid oldies covers and some jazz tunes in the back.  I was drinking a Reinier at a table of 6.  On a Friday/Saturday night, this place is a great place to round up some friends and drink cheaply.  If you don't like the decorations, you're concentrating on the wrong qualities of this place.

There are crazy locals, obnoxious and out-dated decor screwed to the wall, and a sweet alley for smoking.  If you're wearing heels and a fur coat, you might want to go to some of the bourgeoier spots north beach has to offer.
author: L J.

description:
I have nothing to add, except:
- got kicked out of Specs for playing the piano
- because it attracts tourists, I end up meeting random people, like the dutch death guild
- the bartenders are surly (and if I dealt with as many tourists, I would be surly too)
- watch out for the bathroom stairs!!
author: Anna B.

description: If you think this is a dive bar, you haven't been around very much. A dive bar is the Forestville Club, and I'm not going to mention any North Beach dives.  This is NOT a dive, though Specs would probably enjoy having it described that way. The bartenders are great, Specs is irresistible to women of all ages. The drinks are reasonalby priced and it's a place where a woman can feel comfortable going alone. The bartenders keep an eye on things and will intervene if they see a woman is being hassled. The walls are completely covered with art, funny little signs, news articles and photos. It's the best.
author: Marilyn M.

description:
Have you ever wondered what the world looked like from inside an aquarium?  Sit near the front window of Spec's and you can experience that sensation.  Not only does the plate glass cast an eerie blue glow on the outside courtyard, but many of the characters here might very well be water-dwelling.   The bar's nautical motif is something out of bohemian nightmare.
