Glancing up you will see a corpse's head wedged in between the skeletons of two giant shark jaws while John Coltrane jams quietly in the background.  

Apparently, owner of the bar got his nickname from the spectacles he sported back in the day.  Sometimes I feel like I need spectacles to see past the odd-ball facades of the bar patrons.  Upon further examination (eavesdropping), I've discovered that the conservative investment bankers at the table next to me dress in drag on the weekends.  The senile bums at the bar are actually political activists in heated debate about the contributions of Ralph Nader and the evils of the Neo-con movement.  The gentleman keeled over his drink is praying, not snoozing. 

The suffix "-arium" is Latin for "a place for relating to."  Put on your specs, have a couple of cheap Anchor Steams and take a swim with the fish.
author: Kerry D.

description:
The good news: if you want to act like a complete idiot, drink other people's drinks, and physically assault other people's personal property (including expensive guitars) with no repercussions whatsoever, this is the place for you.  There are no consequences for bad behavior here.  It is as permissive a place in San Francisco as you can get nowadays.  Don't worry, you'll never be 86'd or ejected from Spec's.

The bad news: if you've ever stepped away for only a few seconds then turn around to see someone drinking your full pint of beer, imagine this scenario.  You ask the person politely, "Is that my beer?" to which the person responds to you in indecipherable drunken mumbling.  Then before you even get a chance to notify the bartender, the drunk woman finishes your beer and all the bar patrons descend on you and lecture you like you're the asshole picking on a poor thirsty person who is entitled to drink your drink and any other drink she sees.

If that kind of behavior is rewarded at Spec's on a consistent basis, thanks but no thanks.

+1 star for the one female bartender there who is friendly and polite
author: Justin C.

description: Best dive bar in North Beach. When I first got to San Francisco it was full of bikers, suits, old eccentrics, and a few young ins. It is totally fun to people watch. It has so much stuff on the walls, it is worth taking people from out of town.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
i don't know how do you rate a bar that you only go to for one beer?

it was a fine place, decor made me feel like i was in the Saharan Desert in a British outpost there. 

it was crowded on a Wed night
author: Jeff G.

description:
I'd shout GO HERE again but I already used it for my Mars Bar paean. This is a bar for people who love bars. And by that I mean real bars, the kind with some dirt under their fingernails, not the boring recyclable sports bars or the trendy bars that get forgotten as soon as drinks made with huckleberry lose favor.

This bar has history: you can tell by (a) the accumulated crap from all seven seas, (b) the nature of the crap, (c) the dust that the crap has accumulated, and (d) the mix of folks sitting and alternately drinking and spilling their beer. Two guys next to us the last time we were there were old sailors who'd haunted the place 30 years ago, when it was either a merchant sailor's bar or a dyke bar. It's got a complicated history -- you can let your imagination run wild in here.

Plus it's tucked on this little alleyway around the corner from where all the titty bars used to be, back before they became "Gentlemen's Clubs", when this was a sailor's town, and you just know people fought, puked, got their wallet and their false teeth stolen while passed out in the gutter -- basically had an eventful night out.

Don't worry - it's not like that now. But stop in and have a couple of beers, and you'll feel like it could be.
author: Karsten P.

description:
If you want to go to a bar where you have to be quiet and aren't allowed to have any fun....go here. This place sucks balls.

So me and a few friends stroll into this hole, granted we were a little drunk but by no means were we loud at all. We sit down. Our buddy gets us some drinks at the bar and brings it to us. So we go ahead and chug our drinks and the bartender comes to our table, grabs our empty glasses and kicks us out. Why? Because apparently we didn't behave. We didn't disrupt anybody's good time. We weren't loud and obnoxious. I asked her why we were getting kicked out and no response. She just said to leave. So we didn't cause any kind of ruckus. We got up and left. 

If I could give this place negative stars I would.
author: David C.

description:
Not sure why or how we ended up at this little bar in the back of a nowhere alley. 

From now on, when I do decide to brave the NorthBeach crowds, I will make an effort to go here. 

Dark and creepy and cheap and wonderful

I almost had to break my 3 month "no punching" streak. People need to learn how to stare politely and NOT bump into me so they can't "accidentally" touch my ass. Sure I just happened to be wearing what can only be described as an 80's hooker outfit... but that's no excuse.
author: Towanda S.

description:
Spec's is fairly divey but the clientele is mixed with office drones like myself looking to forget our day and older guys who look like they've been drinking long enough to forget several years. I've never been there on a weekend night, so I have not seen it overrun with tourists. The bartenders are fun. The prices are pretty reasonable.

This place is so close to my work, and yet only a few of my co-workers even know it's there. That is actually what gives it the 4th star.
author: Allyson V.

description: One of the most congenial pubs in the city, Spec's makes me feel welcome from the moment I cross the threshold. Accumulated tchotchkes cover every inch of the walls and ceilng, almost as if your pack-rat grandpa's attic exploded inside, and the low yellow lighting makes the whole space feel like a historical scene preserved in amber. Unlike Vesuvio across the street, this isn't a tourist destination -- hence it actually hums with a true beatnik vibe. I haven't seen any of the old-timers here break into cosmic verse, but I can easily imagine the literary ghosts of poetic North Beach hiding in the corners. And speaking of old-timers, Spec's is definitely a hangout for the wizened and wise. No bellowing young fratboys here, just a clutch of pensive older folks who like to share lagers and laffs over a worn wooden table.
author: John G.

description:
Read across the street at City Lights until it's appropriate drinking time. 

Head to Spec's no later than 6ish and you'll be treated to cheese at happy hour.

Old style SF, comfortable atmosphere, all the usual North Beach characters and stiff drinks. You won't need anything else.
author: katy h.

description:
Specs is a pretty cool bar to just chill in. When I went there it got kinda crowded, but the place is pretty small. Also some middle-aged guys were playing Magic cards behind us and had all their role playing game figures out. I dunno. 

Anyway.... the decor is great, filled to the brim with a maritime theme. I even saw a bumper sticker for Tybee Island, GA, a place I used to frequent when I was in college. 

Also, they have a wheel of cheese they cut for you and crackers.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Yeah, this place's name just rolls right off the tongue, doesn't it?

Spec's is hidden away across the street from Vesuvio in North Beach, and it's one fine little bar for sure. First thing I noticed was the sheer volume of (for lack of a better word) crap on the walls. Fun stuff to look at when you're waiting for another drink (which, by the way, is a refreshingly short wait). There's a ton of authentic flags hanging from the ceiling, too, so all this totally adds to the quirky atmosphere.

Drinks are good and strong, bartenders are very attentive, and it has a really laid-back ambience. Well, until the trashed friend you're with falls over and breaks one of the tables. Then it's not so laid-back. And then, apparently, you get kicked out. Oh well, no matter, as I said Vesuvio's a cigarette drag away!
author: Drew S.

description:
Spec's is cool. Never dull. Always something to look at.
I like that it's off the beaten path so you aren't trampled when you step out for a smoke or something, though bums run a muck. 
Cash only which can be a drag but there are atms to boot in the area. 
There's also the Tamale man, a Spec's regular, usually in a bowling or Hawaiian shirt and glasses and a hat, super friendly, and if hot tamales are your thang, it's always better to drink with a full tummy than an empty one. 
I love the art and kitchiness of everything about Spec's. From the New Guinea "calendar" by the booths in the corner to the "ovaries" sign for the Ladie's room. 

And remember:
You can't spell SPECTACULAR without Spec's!
author: Mary Ella D.

description: What do you get when you cross a sleezy nautical museum, a beat poet landmark and a wheel of cheese? Specs! One of my favorite low-key places in the city to get a simple drink from a good looking bartender. I have a feeling this place hasn't changed in 50 years and I'm kind of ok with that.
author: Jeska D.

description:
Truly one of the most novel and interesting bars I've been to in the city. And when I say bars, I mean "bars"! This is a no-frills kind of joint but it contains some of the most interesting eye-candy I've seen since moving here last year. Maps, flags, newspaper articles...everything San Fransisco and then some. The beer is cold, the bartenders cool and the old-school cheese cutter behind the bar is fantastic.

When you want to just enjoy a beer with a friend or group of friends and don't need all the hassles of being in a "trendy" spot, this is one great place to enjoy yourself. A definite "must-see" for those friends who come out for a visit to SF!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
I love this kicked back, tucked away, friendly and cozy bar. 

not exceptional drinks--but very decent - just an all-around great place and great tenders, too. Make it a night with Tosca's, Vesuvio's, Specs and you better get something to eat or you'll be sorry (La Gondola? Bocadilloes, or my favorite: start out at L'Osteria and then get unwound on the bar triangle)

perfectly situated on my walk from work down near the pier to downtown to catch a bus...a great North beach dive locale. (you shouldn't be driving after this)
author: Liza B.

description: Pretty cool unique place- based on the reviews, I was expecting a terrible place with a bunch of washed up elderly malcontents. Since it was St. Patricks Day, they knew probably to stay the hell away. After all St Pats along with a few other holidays are amateur drinking days. Place was packed, as much like us, others discovered every place in NB was completely packed. They had Guiness, and good bartenders. No TV, but that didn't come as a surprise....
author: Jim B.

description:
There are very few bars in the North Beach area that you can go into where there aren't lurkers in every corner waiting for some poor girl to get drunk so they can pounce on her. Very few gold chains and unbuttoned shirts here. 

 This place is a nice hideaway from that kind of crowd. It's nestled in an alleyway so most tourists aren't going to catch it.  The bar has a really mellow vibe to it and the decor, while kitschy, isn't overbearing. It's got a nice balance of quirky yet relevant. They also mean business with their drinks here. One of the only bars where I have to ask for less alcohol in my drink!
author: Jade L.

description:
First time here after strolling about looking for a new place to try.  Have always wonder about this place.  Tucked away with interesting characters out front smoking...it's always the whiff of grass that catch my attention.  I often wonder if that's the designated legal location - why else will anyone be doing in such blatant public?  

It is somewhat of a neighborhood dive bar that's semi clean with some bench seatings along one wall and some other round tables near the back.  I don't get the museum part but I did enjoy checking out the articles, pics and whatnots on the wall and ceiling.  There are board games such as Battleship and Sorry, chess, a few books and other reading materials available for your enjoyment.  There is a beat up looking upright piano in the back near the bathroom.  Walking toward the bathroom - you'll see a very small sign "Sit down" with a left arrow and "Stand up" with a straight arrow.  The door to the stall in the "sit down" does not lock but it has toilet paper covers, which is a nice and surprising find.

The place is dimly lit but your eyes will adjust.  It is definitely a good place to people watch - quite a diverse group of interesting people.  The bar was full when we got there so we ordered our beer (Widmer Hef - $5 each) and took a seat across from it.  Didn't see the cheese someone mentioned and didn't know they have it until someone ordered cheese and crackers...
author: Gloria H.

description:
I don't know how it took me 7 years to come here, but this place is c-o-o-l cool. Perfect to place to sit down with friends and catch up. My buddy some how ordered cheese from the bartendress and it hit the spot. 

I'll be back soon ... very soon.
author: Allen X.

description:
Weird, freaky and mysterious, yet irresistibly intriguing for newcomers. Warm, welcoming and emblematic about everything I love about SF for those who frequent it.

Equally acceptable to be quietly reading a book at the bar -- under the reading lamp if you get there first -- as it is to be playing domino, raucously shouting and laughing with seven friends at one of the tables. 

Piano out back that gets a professional to sit down and play even late at night.

Eccentric gentlemen selling artwork and photos inside and out. 

Cheap, strong dirty martinis, plenty of whiskys, Anchor on tap and Oly in can. 

A whale's penis hangs above the bar, while the bar's correspondence -- from correspondents flung all over the world -- sits on top of it. 

Nothing else like it in the anywhere, in this world or the next. 

Long live Specs.
author: Chris R.

description:
Spec's is a San Francisco institution.  What other dive bar in the city can you walk into and feel like you're entered a local history museum only to take a deep breath and recognize the tell tale smell of a well used bar.  All the wood in this place must be fully marinated with beer from the years of usage.  It doesn't matter what walk of life you come from, once you walk in the door you're home.  I'd dare say that its the Cheers of San Francisco... you wanna go where people know, people are all the same, you wanna be where you can see, our troubles are all the same.  

One a side note: I've heard the old wive's tale that there was once a secret back door into the strip bar that is now the Hustler club.  Who knows if that is legit, but it doesn't matter.  I will always love Spec's for what it represents: the illustrious history of San Francisco's alcohol and subversive loving population.
author: Ms. M. M.

description:
Monday Night 12:00.

Finally make it to Specs from Pearl's, were we find the other half of our group who were up to no good.  Sit down for some more drinks and I see a basket of cheese and crackers pass me by.  Another brilliant snack!  As we frequent this bar i have already ooo'd and aah'd over its beauty and enjoy conversation with my friends and all the neighborhood locals.  No specs sighting tonight.  Finally end our night at 2:00, so sad but it is Monday.  Can't wait for next week.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
What a cool little bar ! I didnt even know it was there until a friend suggest we meet here last week. Its cool. 
I met a random old man at the bar who decided to share his life story with us. 
The service was quick and all drinks we served with a smile. 
And whats with the cheese????????? 
he he 
I like it !
author: Amy W.

description:
It would make more sense to give Specs 1 star if it would keep the assholes at the kind of bars they deserve. I don't know what you're looking for expecting to find anything else at Specs than a good goddamn local bar. 

If you want woman, go hit up the strip clubs up the street. Amazing customer service? Pay for it at the Ritz hotel bar on Nob Hill. You want novelty, I recommend Visuvios across the street.

If you're looking for character in a spot awash in history, this is it. I love this bar and the most of the people tending to the bar. My only complaint is that people that couldn't have a good time with a manual (Where is the party?) on their search for the unknown ruin the experience on weekends and leave confused reviews.
author: David V.

description:
I was only in specs one time for about 15 minutes and I only had a Corona so I can't really say much about the place...the atmosphere is quite interesting, Tiki meets old dive bar, and the restrooms are clean and nice. But the main reason I am writing this review is for my boyfriend who believes that world should know this one piece of info...

SPECS MAKES THE WORLDS BEST IRISH COFFEE

Now, my Boyfriend is Irish, and his standby day time drink is Irish coffee...and he is VERY, VERY picky. He took one sip of Specs Irish coffee and told me I needed to write a yelp review on the place because it was the very best Irish coffee he's had in his entire life.

So there you have it...if you like Irish Coffee, go to Specs! OH, BTW...they will not make an Irish Car Bomb at this place...I only know because I witnessed a patron attempting to get the bartender to make one....she refused.
author: Summer S.

description:
Okay, I may be rating this lower because it's not really my type of scene - I prefer newer amenities, and not to be a bitch, but ya know what I mean?  It's like $12 drinks anywhere and I'm not sure what sets this place apart.

It was neat though, in a vintage sort of way - like passing a thrift store and thinking, "Oh, that is so cool - I bet that dress was hot, in the 50s"  but it's not like you can bring back an era - nor do I agree with montage dressing.

Anyhow, this place had it coolness and a chill scene filled with a little granolas a little eclectic and some gay - gotta give it props for diversity.  
Margaritas were nice, but like five sips small.

Not a bad place by any means, but I won't be returning unless I'm with a group and we need to make consensus on where to venture to next.

The ambiance was like a funny little oddly shaped place, brimming with artifacts.  I'm deeming it Grandpa's Attic
author: Lauren G.

description:
Probably my favorite historical bar in the city. Dingy, dirty and antiquated, this place is a total time machine. I'd be shocked if anything's been touched (much less cleaned) here in the last 40 years. The bartenders here are curt, but get it right, and even though it can change on a dime, the crowd here always seems to be cool.

An all time classic.
author: Andrew L.

description: This is a classic North Beach bar. The cool museum-like artifacts that adorn the walls remind me of Tommy's Joynt on Van Ness. There's nothing like this bar. It's very authentic. I got to meet Specs at his birthday party. There was so much food and I kept ordering dirty Shirley's. I had a great time, but it's not a very young crowd. There's a lot of strange older men who hang out there. It's quiet and charming. Be good to Specs' and pray that a guy like Specs never leaves the world. I think it's the kind of place that writers are to hang out at.
author: Denise C.

description:
A lot has changed in San Francisco, but thankfully, change comes slow to Specs.

I was first lured into Specs' in 1991 on my birthday by a haggard bar fly my friends and I met down the street at the SF Brewing Company. When she found out it was my birthday, she exclaimed in a gavelly voice: "Oh, you have to have a drink at Specs! I'll bring you...it'll be okay."

We only found out later why it might not be okay.

Anyway, we followed our bar fly friend over to Specs...which was actually down a short alley. The door was almost hidden in the back corner. When we walked in, a group of four men at the bar turned to stare us down.

"It's okay boys, they're with me."

Our friend seemed to have some sway in Specs and they all went back to their drink.

Meanwhile, our eyes had to soak up all the fantastic treasure hanging from the walls. Old WWII posters warning Americans about loose lips. A skull lodged in a hole in the wall. An actual letter in a bottle with all its history of correspondence. Maps. Gear. You name it.

And then we had our fortunes read and drowned ourselves in cheap beer, counting the cockroaches scurrying across the floor toward the flooded bathroom. Classic!

These days, like the rest of SF, Specs is much more well-heeled. But it's still got a little edge and all the maritime treasures are still on display.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Ah, Specs.  This was one of my dad's haunts, back in the day.  

The predominantly male crowd are either young, bespeckled guys who use the word 'fella', as in: 

"I knew this fella named Tom."  

Having you believe that they talk like Holden Caulfield all the time.  The kind who fancy themselves intellectuals, who think that because they have/still do, work/ed at City Lights , and they drink at Vesuvio's, and Specs, and the Saloon, and they get their coffee at Cafe Trieste that somehow all that makes them beatnik.   

The majority, however, are sad old guys who drink too much.  Guys my dad's age who still think they can pick up on you, and impress you with stories of way back when.  And how cool it was to trip on acid with Alan Ginsburg, or some shit.  

Apparently Spec's is also host to nude model drawing classes on Sunday mornings.  Gross.

Two stars for historical significance, both in establishment and in patronage.
author: Emily X.

description:
Just had a happy hour with friends earlier today, and we decided to meet at Spec's.  I had never been there before, so I had no idea what to expect.  The bar was tucked away in a little corner, and if you were looking for a palce with a big "SPECS" sign, you'd probably miss it.

The inside is decorated with all kinds of weird stuff... a true "museum" of old items, including random street signs, old hats, ivory smoke pieces, etc.  We couldn't figure out if there was any theme... just as long as the item was old and cool-looking.

The crowd was a really random mix of old "earthy"-looking folks and younger people getting a drink after work.  Not necessarily the type of place I usually go to, but it was chill and a good place to hang out.  There was plenty of room, and the bar was easily accessible.  However, since NCAA tourney games were going on and there were no TVs, we decided to migrate shortly after arriving.  All-in-all, an ok spot.

S uch a random assortment of old things inside.
P lenty of table space and room to mix & mingle.
E very type of person is welcome here.
C an be a bit hard to find, unless you know what you're looking for.
S imple and chill.  A decent place to get a drink.
author: Kenny L.

description: Most interesting bar I've come across in San Fran.  They give you a big hunk of delicious cheese when you come in.  Lots of crazy and historic things on the walls and ceiling. Definitely a place to check out.
author: Darren R.

description:
Oh the brain cells I have destroyed in this bar! I remember like yesterday my first time there in 1995.....
Back......Back........Back.......
*bouncing in like a young scoolgirl* 
Me: "May I have a Coors Light and a shot of Yager?!"
Mark, The bartender : "We don't serve that here!!!!!"
Me: * fluffing my hair* , " Gee! Why Not?"
Mark: *fluffing his hair*, "Well, Young Lady, it's because WE are a union bar , and union bars DON'T sell Coors Light!"
Me: "Oh!....But whyfore no Yager?"
Mark: "Because we have to clean our own bathrooms, Young Miss!"
Me:*brightning* ,"Well, that makes perfect sense! I will have a Bud and a shot of Tequila!"
And that was the start of a BEAUTIFUL love story.... With both Specs and maybe just a teeny bit with Mark......!
author: Lara D.

description:
NICE cross section of pizza stained shirt fronts, aging conspiracy theorists and cute, drunk unattended girls being treated with care. I liked this place. God knows I would have liked anything after searching for parking on a Saturday night, but it was a treat to end up here. It almost had a wee Cheers feel, as in, there are some interesting regulars who actually enjoy newbies.

The drinks are STRONG and that is always the best recommendation for a bar. Maybe it's because they have been practicing since 1968. The place is owned by locals and it shows in the menagerie of art and commentary that this place can hang its hat on. I have included some other URLs with info ~ 

Make it your last stop on a tour of North Beach so you can get some sanity after weaving your way through all the bachelor parties and bridge and tunnelers tweaking on the full nudes. It is a welcome respite.

www.bestofsanfrancisco.net/specs.htm
www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/01/26/BAG2C4HM0A1.DTL&type=travelbayarea
author: Miel H.

description:
Smelly, dark, and hip.  Come here to write the great-American novel or take a wiff of the B.O. which makes this place unique and a legend of North Beach.  On Wednesdays, their is a mtg of some writers (not sure who), but for one-dollar, you can pick up their weekly-zine.  SF poet laureate makes this his home.

Cash only.
author: Olis L.

description: Hidden gem. Love the atmosphere. One of my favorites in North Beach.
author: Anny P.

description:
Spec's is a pleasant little dive bar tucked away in a mini alleyway off Columbus in the North Beach. They have a lot of old dusty artifacts and photos decorating the walls.

I enjoyed grabbing a drink and chilling at the back listening to the bluesy piano player finishing up his set before closing.  Not a bad way to end the night.
author: Sam T.

description:
3 stars because it's unique and more adult for the area but no happy hour? 5 bucks an undersized pint?  Come on.  Nearly all the competitors in nb are half this price at happy hour at least.
Cash only to me is just bogus in this day and age. Pay the couple percentage points Mr. Owner your prices are steep enough.
Also no tv's so if you wanna watch a game forget it.
author: Kyle K.

description: Awesome atmosphere. Fantastic Sidecars. Specs reminded me of what it's like to indulge in a well-crafted classic cocktail.
author: Katie S.

description:
Love Spec's...it's one of my favorite SF bars.  I love taking out-of-town guests here as it has that feeling of old school SF.  Whenever I'm here I always feel like I'm the only person who knows about the place even though I know it's hardly a secret.

It's always confusing setting up a meetup there...some people call it Spec's, others the Adler Museum and still others "that place in the corner in North Beach". You'll figure it out though.

Simple place with a nice feel to it unless your date likes to always order chocolate martinis like mine does.  I would stick to beer and simple concoctions of harder juice at this place.

The bric-a-brac hanging on the walls makes for good conversation once you get done talking about how confused you all were in finding the place.

I've never had a problem with the Irish bartender but I can see how people would.  One time he berated a bachelor party that was getting noisy ("PIPE DOWN!") and another time a group of guys smoking pot outside the bar.  He told us that he doesn't have a problem with pot but "He doesn't like the pipes!!"  I found all of this funny (when was the last time you heard someone ask someone else to pipe down?) but if you get treated rudely yourself it's certainly off-putting.

You'll tend to meet a ton of local characters here.  Once I was drinking whiskey with a guy who was 93 and had a ton of crazy old school San Francisco stories.  Keep an eye out for Specs himself (you'll know him when you see him); he routinely hands out business cards and is quite a dapper fellow so keep your eyes on your lady!
author: Steve B.

description: as a grumpy bitter drunk, I love a place I can go an be grumpy with a rich history of grumpy people.
author: John X.

description: A quiet, tucked away bar with tons of style and no pomp.  Good drinks, good staff and a great location (where they aren't constantly blasting music).  This place is a wonderland of bric-a-brac (earning its wings as a museum) and even has an old dictionary for use.
author: Thomas G.

description: Great place with a nice divey, local feel.  With a decent selection of beers, even Olympia, and full bar, it is a good place to get a couple drinks and look around at all the stuff cluttering the walls, I was quite impressed to see a very old IWW banner.
author: Orin B.

description:
Have always loved this dive.  It's local.  It's not so hip.  It's retro.  And the secret is coming in after work, and leaving before 8pm.  The bartender from Germany is awesome.  Nothing like serving drinks, Gouda and no smile.  Love her.

After 8, totally different crowd.  More of the tunnel crowd w/ their oh so naive nieces and nephews from the Midwest.  Can you say " I think we're not in Kansas anymore, toto."

Regardless, great rocking place.  Very subtle and hidden (sort-of).  Who knows you might find that Mr. or Ms. Right or maybe just Mr. or Ms. Right Now.
author: Rod '.

description:
Did you ever wish you were Herman Melville just off the boat, and ready to rid yourself the raincoat and boots and wax poetic about the white whale or the mutiny you seemed to have avoided?

Well spec's is your place.

My personal favorite thing about this bar is that they serve gouda and saltines! (at least i think it's gouda, the circular whitish cheese wrapped in that waxy red coating???). There are grumbling foagy regulars that talk a lot of shit, and many seem to get kicked out. A lot of rogue traffic seem to pop in to start trouble....just like in a Melville novel.

The decor sports lots of martime regalia, and i love the lighting, this place is a good one to take your dad, especially if they like to drink.
author: wayne s.

description: Do not come here. I don't want too many people finding out about this place. I only accidentally hit the five star rollover. Nothign to see, move along!
author: Darren M.

description:
Nice location, interesting clientele and decor. Decent beer selection - fourth star is because they have Olympia!

Warning: there is always a homeless person sleeping in here.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Probably one of my favorite neighborhood bars.  Everyone I've taken here loves the old European feel to this place.  I've yet to be disappointed whenever I come here looking for a relaxed evening in a bar filled with character.  At any given point there might be a couple of people at the piano playing an impromptu jam session or an odd character or two lurking in the corner with a story to tell if you're feeling chatty.  

The bartenders here are as full of character as the bar itself and who doesn't like a place that serves up wedges of cheese...heaven!
author: T V.

description:
Star Number 1:  Cool bar in a touristy area tucked away from all the tourists
Star Number 2:  Cocktails are well priced and taste decent
Star Number 3:  Lots of stuff to look at when you've run out of money and aren't quite ready to leave and face the outside world
Star Number 4:  It's a divey bar with "character" and lots of characters
Star Number 5:  The big honking wheel of cheese.
author: Jenny K.

description:
This was the third stop for a Friday happy hour with my co-workers and due to the fact that we had been drinking since 4:30 without dinner (and got here at 8:30), I have to admit that I don't think I really got a good feel for Spec's.

I had a great time and it was a nice little dive, but I really can't give many details. Maybe it deserves 5 stars or maybe 3, but until I can go back in a more sober state, I'll have to give it 4 for now! But I'm sure I'll definitely be going back soon!
author: Elaine S.

description: This is a classic in San Francisco!  I always have an interesting conversation with a complete stranger. The place exudes history!
author: Jeff F.

description:
My favorite bar in SF. 

Order the cheese and cracker plate, and watch the bartender cut a wedge of Edam off the round behind the bar. its a truly unique contraption. yes, a guillotine. like someone else already said. 

if you are looking for decent conversation, and some true history in a North Beach establishment, check out Specs.
author: david j.

description:
A semi-secret North Beach gem soaked in locals, tourists, and weekend invaders; a genuine slice of San Francisco history. Its not hard to imagine the company of leather-handed sailors, one-eyed pirates, and beer-slinging wenches with all the museum relics from the Barbary Coast  or the presence of Jack and Alan at the end of the bar.

Buy a book at City Lights, order an Irish Coffee and a block of cheese from the gypsy, and settle down at a salty stool for a Sunday afternoon read. When you need a break from the book, thumb through one of the baskets of postcards from decades past. Specs is authentic San Francisco at its best.
author: Eric ..

description:
If Vesuvio is eclectic, then Specs is downright peculiar. Strange art on the walls, stranger clientele.

I love that the entance is not just off the street. To get in you have to intend to be here, or you must be curious. I like curious people.  

I've had some strange times here, from handing hankies to girlfriends crying their eyes out over the perfidy of men, to happy silly times with easy rounds of beer.

The interior has a lot of wood which creates a very warm ambiance. Again, not a place to get a fancy frou-frou over-thought, over-priced paean to mixology. This is a charming place to drink with people you want to have good conversation with.
author: Claudius R.

description:
A guy and I met here for a first date, and I definitely had trouble finding this bar, which was down a random alley near Broadway and Columbus.  Finally locating it, I was amazed by the decor.  I never in a million years expected this kind of dive bar in the middle of North Beach.  Junk is EVERYWHERE, which makes for great conversation and really gives the place character.  Whiskey shots ensued with the bartender and every time I've been to this bar since it's a tradition for me to have at least one shot of Jameson during my stay.  

One of the most random experiences I've had here occurred when a man in a full 19th century fancy suit quietly strolled in and sat next to me.  The bartender took one look at him, pulled out a huge wheel of cheese and within minutes had a platter for him- I kid you not.  Later on, the man went out to buy sushi for the bartenders and himself, leaving the cheese as a "gift" to my friend and me.  That's what I love about this place- the comfortable familiarity with random characters and how down to earth everyone is.

On a side note, the dive aspect of this bar results in terrible bathrooms.  Oh well, it comes with the territory.  Give this place a try for sure- you won't be disappointed and it's a great reprieve from overpriced North Beach bars!
author: Jessica C.

description:
you wanna know what's nice about specs? people are happy here. HAPPY. 

i know weird, right? but think about it, who ever really looks happy when they're out anymore? if they aren't obsessed with how their outfit looks or trying to get laid they're pissed off they can't get a drink fast enough. 

not so at specs. the crowd here feels very neighbor-y. people are wearing dirty jeans and tee shirts. they're wearing their comfy boots and jackets. they like it in here. they're drinking beer mostly and actually conversing with each other instead of pretending to be at ease when really their eyes are darting around the room like crazy cause they really, really need to get laid. 

if you skip the beer and opt for a cocktail you can rest assured it won't be weak. this is another place you shouldn't bother wearing any good shoes to, the floors are dirty and they like them that way.
author: rachel p.

description:
When I looked this place up to review it, I wasn't sure if this was the right place until I read the reviews and looked at the pics.  But yes it is the same place.  

So it's a Museum Cafe I think, but to me it looked like a bar with a lot of probably historical stuff on the walls and decor.  I probably should have noticed it all more and maybe even tried to look at the stuff, but in reality, it was midnight and thought I was the driver for the  night, I just wanted to sit down with a sprite or something!  

Drinks here are cheap, service is fast, everyone in here is happy and smiling.  Everyone in there was sitting at little tables having a really good time drinking and hanging out with friends.  Differs from the typical North beach scene, as it's casual, and you can hear what the other person is saying.  I guess because it's a museum, everything in here is older and more vintagey looking also.  Not a dive bar per se, but just a vintagey place I guess for lack of better words.  For awhile there was even live piano music which was nice in-between the great conversations.
author: Denise B.

description:
I dropped into Spec's for a birthday party, for this guy I didn't know, exactly, but he invited me so I showed up. That was last month.

I've come back like four times. You can't get me out of this bar! But why is everyone calling it a dive? It's no dive; it's a sea shanty with walls.

I guess I'd blown a substantial chunk of my paycheck when the bartender said, "Four dollars, dear -- I'm buying your drink." What I'm saying is, you can cultivate your 'regular' status in two seconds flat.

I've already watched several couples on dates here. What a good idea! This is my new favorite bar.
author: Jenn X.

description: Definitely a hidden gem. Will be returning next time I'm in North Beach.
author: Ravenna P.

description: My favorite bar in North Beach. Douche free. Amazing  bartenders. Interesting regulars.
author: Vanessa G.

description:
Love the atmosphere here. Great dive and I love that it's a bit hidden from the rest of the North Beach shananagins. All bars should be required to have random crap on the walls. Makes the people I'm with all that more interesting.

Got in a little argument with the bartender about the difference between a snake bite and a black velvet and thought he was being a dick, but we ended up agreeing to disagree and had a good chat about it actually. I guess I'll never know the proper name for that drink...

I'll be going back
author: Sarah P.

description:
I'll wager that Specs is the one true dive bar in North Beach. It's like this little oasis of authenticity in a desert of tourism. I say this as a frequent , unabashed tourist of the area ... I'm the guy who comes through town on business once or twice a month and wanders up here from Union Square in search of books, booze and Beats.  Totally insufferable, and completely unapologetic.  If it means anything, I am on a constant quest to dine and drink where the locals do, preferring to eschew my own kind and find out where the quality of service and goods are both high enough to impress the residents. 

Anyhow, Specs -- all credit to my buddy Adam (now a full-time resident of the city) for turning me onto this place.  We once held up a couple of barstools here for most of a Monday holiday after crawling our way down the street from the Rogue Public House, City Lights and Cafe Trieste. We rolled in around 4:30 p.m.  4 hours and 4 or 5 whiskeys later, we realized we'd passed one of the better evenings of our acquaintance just sitting there, shooting the shit with the regulars, reading our books and sipping some of Ireland's finest (if you're keeping score at home, that means Jameson's). The bartender brought us some delicious cheese and Saltines and introduced us to her daughter, who'd just wandered in to show mom her new tattoo (a Hawaiian dancer with her mother's name wriggling on the belly). 

The clientle is a good mix of crusty regulars doing their livers no favors, familiar writerly types who occasionally stop to post a recent poem on the bulletin board and younger patrons like me and Adam, taking the bait on all manner of conversational fishing lines.

We got into an animated discussion with one older regular over the meaning of the word "Huckleberry," trying to discern its definiton from contextual clues in both Henry Mancini's "Moon River," ("my huckleberry friend") and the movie Tombstone ("I'm your huckleberry"). I sought advice from Dictionary.com via my trio, and then Wikipedia -- but our partner in the back-and-forth was having none of it ("All that Internet stuff is complete crap!"). After disappearing from the bar for a good half-hour or more, he re-appeared at the bar spouting the definition at top volume, having gone across the street to City Lights bookstore to look it up in a slang dictionary.  

That's Specs. If you're looking for a shot, rube, keep walking.
author: Sean F.

description:
I caught this place out of the corner of my eye when trying to flee Apartment 24 as quickly as possible. Wait a second.....cafe/bar and MUSEUM!!! 

I could sit here for hours looking at all that kitschy shit on the walls. Bartenders are awfully nice and they have legit drunks at the bar, all in all a great dive bar for me.
author: Kara S.

description:
When I want to sit down and drink with friends in North Beach I come here. 

It's my favorite Bar bar. Do yourself a favor and have them slice some cheese for you. I believe it's fontina. They serve it with saltines and I wouldn't have it any other way.
author: Angela K.

description: Great old school SF place. Good mix crowd.
author: Mark S.

description:
The bartenders were great, the crowd was fun and the vibe was old time North Beach dive bar.  What really made it special was the guy who sat down and played the piano and shouted the blues like Booker T. Lawry in a New Orleans whorehouse.  Totally cool until somebody started requesting boring duelling piano bar type fare.
For the dude who told everyone that it was great to hear some James Brown when the guy played What'd I Say - well, I'm just glad you were digging it!
Check it out.
author: Steve G.

description:
Cozy little bar across the road from Vesuvio's with way more character. The drinks are cheap, they serve beers in pitchers, and it is easy to get a table if you come early.

$14 pitchers of Sierra is pretty awesome. Place is decked out with crap everywhere, but its a nice homely style of crap. Flags on the roof, and random signs are everywhere.

Only one gripe, make space on the bar for people ordering drinks. The barfly's never leave, and your always reaching over them to get a drink. It's not an uncommon issue here, make it easy to order drinks and I will do so.
author: Joseph T.

description:
Been going here since 16 years old, this place is just awesome in every way. Defines what a bar with character is. My only advice is to avoid weekends because of crowds and the type of people they bring. Weekdays are much better. Additionally, they make a great martini though my usual is usually Jameson over with a beerback... 
I was happy the day they added beers to the tap (forever it was Bud only)
author: Brian Aaron J.

description: We tried to sing Christmas carols here and were told to leave by the female bartender on Sunday.  Bah hum bug Adler, guess you don't want 12 people to buy drinks.
author: Ian M.

description:
best bar in north beach- hands down. Great crowd - great bartenders-great drinks. 

This goes for people who are more into the dive bar feel - meeting some strange people perhaps - story telling- looking at crazy shit on the walls.
author: Kelley B.

description: Dive bar with flair (think Office Space) contributed by stevedores and shipmates the world round. This bar's character feels genuine.
author: Anton A.

description:
Museums and alcohol...... SFMOMA, De young and Exploratorium could learn a lot from this place.

An experience worth experiencing.
A place to sit worth sitting.
A drink worth drinking.
A listen worth listening.
author: Po L.

description: Is this place formally a San Francisco historical landmark?  It should be.  Check out the history of the place on the wall, it goes back a hundred years to early Chinese workers.  The bartenders are stupendous, from the men's room you get a view underneath the sidewalk above, the drinks are reasonable, and they have a giant wheel of fontina cheese.  It's where I meet friends when I need an honest bar and even more honest conversation, and where I take out-of-towners to show them a little local culture.
author: David A.

description:
This place is great.
Cluttered, quirky and low key old school neighborhood bar with a good mix of regulars, eccentrics and some touristy types (who don't seem to stay all that long, probably looking for someting a bit more north beachy)
Prices are ok as is the service, neither are the reason most come in.
Always have a good time, though never had the time of my life.
Great for a drink and a conversation.
One of those "gotta try it at least once" places.
author: Sam R.

description:
I had a wonderul party here for my birthday.  
I even had Victor's pizza deliver a few pizzas here for the party goers.
All i can say is come here on a NON WEEKEND night and even if it is a weekend stay to see the old drunk men.  
They only do simple classic drinks, dont ask for a Cosmo here.
One of the best nights of my life was spent here retelling a beautiful story about my father, and as the old men bought me shots,  as they sang with me, laughed with me, and as my girlfriends sat around and chatted up a storm i began to rethink the idea of hanging out in North Beach at night.  

Sipping on a nice glass of whiskey, and watching the elder folk next to me getting yelled at by the young bartender, or sitting at the bar with a friend going through the old postcards whatever it be, Specs is a classic  San Francisco watering hole that has yet to be poisined by the modern day beat hipsters that walk the streets of the mission.  
BUT!!!! on the weekends I'd stay away...thats when the dark side of the Marina comes out.
author: Tina d.

description:
Oh man!
My favorite bar in North Beach.
This is where all the locals tend to hang out.
I've made many friends here.
I love the staff and the piano player.
Don't let the crowds on the weekends scare you away from this bar.
author: Jess L.

description:
refer to review also dated today for colosseo restaurant.

go to specs.
author: Mr G.

description:
Quite possibly the best that old San Francisco has to offer. Don't go here looking for singles or that designer booze hitting the shelves these days. Specs is my old local bar where there is an eclectic mix of evreything and everyone. Sean and Dancer are gone but the bar is still one of my favorite hang outs. Check your attitude at the door and belly up to the bar for a drink. During the week is best when they have the postcard bins out. Read about the travels of the Spec faithful. 

I even found a postcard I sent from 5 years ago. Some things never change, I'm grateful Specs hasn't changed! Enjoy!
author: Ryan M.

description:
I, over the past several weeks, have said to my very supportive group of yelp friends "I really think my 500th review needs to be about a bar, but one that means something to me. You know, one that is special, one that houses a lot of memories and has been there throughout my many years in San Francisco. What do you think?", 

I expected a barrage of ideas. I thought these people were actually paying attention. I thought our times together were special and my stories were entertaining. I have given them a lot of love, and time, since meeting them. I am sure I gave them a pretty good glimpse into my life before yelp. 

Instead I was met with a whole lot of blank stares, a lot of unintelligible mumbling, the excuse "You have already written reviews of all of the places we have been" and the idea that I have no more bars left to write about. In short, I discovered that my friends have the attention span of a fifth of vodka. 

Well, bitches, sober up for just a minute! I have a whole lot of bar review left in this pickled brain, despite my best efforts to forget the last 6 months of my life and quite possibly other bits and pieces prior. You will not again forget that there are thousands of bars in this city, and that I have been to most of them. You will remember that there are plenty of places we have been together that I have yet to review.

Specs is the bar I have chosen to help me try to jog your memory and show you the way. If you have not been here with me you will go. I will tell you stories of other bars I haven't yet reviewed. I will get you drunk and reference your behavior in future bar reviews. You will learn to pay attention. Or you will get drunk and forget. 

Okay, now that we are clear, and without further ado, here is my 500th review;

I have been to Specs at least as many times as I have sat down to my computer to write a review. I still don't know what the hell is hanging all over the walls. I am pretty sure they hang it all up to make you dizzy so you will throw up and they can subsequently throw you out (crowd control). Good thing I am a professional and would never get sick staring at a bunch of photos of convicts in their underwear getting ready to be eaten by a large stuffed fish. It is good that I am not a sensitive gal who would drunk cry over sad stories in small type. It is also good that they serve cheese, cut off a huge wheel in the middle of the bar. It is good that the people who drink here are patient enough to wait in the hallway while people do things in the restrooms. It is good that they have a bartender named Dancer, who is not actually a reindeer, because it would be hard to pour a strong G&T with hooves. It is good that they cleaned up the front and added urns of flowers and lights so that you don't trip on a homeless person on your way out. It is good that people are friendly, since the tables in the back are large and often shared by 10 people. It is good that there is still a place in North Beach that is not full of complete assholes trying to fight each other or grope you, depending on their mood. 

It is good that my friends remember our times here...............

wait, ummm....anyhow, just go to Specs. And try to remember why it is so good.
author: Drue C.

description: On a weekend trip to San Francisco, my Husband and I stumbled upon this absolutely amazing little bar! The people were absolutely the nicest, even got a short history lesson of the building of San Francisco. The bartender was the sweetest...!! We felt like we knew her forever....!!! The memorabilia on the wall is fantastic...!!!
author: Wendy S.

description: Odd mix of folks in this small bar. It might be refreshing at times, but also can get a little depressing. It also looks as though people take the opportunity to play all sorts of games here, from role playing to chess. So, if that's your bag, you might want to frequent this bar more often...
author: Nicolas H.

description: It's Heinold's First and Last Chances twin sister.   Jack London would be proud.
author: Jen L.

description: This bar, the patrons, the decor -- all of it made me want to kill myself.  Definitely a last stop kind of place.
author: Eugene F.

description: They serve cheese and crackers!  They let you order in pizza!  They pour Guinness properly (pour a bit, let it settle, pour a bit more, let it settle, top it off, serve)!  I freakin' love Spec's ... I just wish it was a bit bigger.  Oh, and the outdoor seating is a bench by the door!
author: William A.

description: It's supposedly divey but it's way too bright. You're not supposed to see who you're going to have awful drunken sex with when you're in a "dive" bar like this. Second, they have a Carlsberg sign on the outside but don't actually offer it. Don't be such a tease, Spec's!
author: Maria D.

description: Please don't come here. You'll ruin it for the rest of us.
author: Brett L.

description:
spec's has a million reviews and if you live in SF, i'm sure you already know spec's or been there etc.

lets me say that i just don't get to spec's as much as i like.

it's one of the best bars in san francisco hands down.

it's one of the places in san francisco that makes me feel so lucky to live here.

spec's is "san francisco" down to its very core.

plus, the best fight i have ever saw happened in front of spec's.

its wasn't bloody or drunk girls or midgets.

it was two homeless poets arguing over bukowski and then started to throw books at each other from their respectful milk crates full of books.

only in north beach, only at spec's.
author: erik H.

description: Cool/bizarre SF place.  One of a kind with an eclectic clientele.  the rating is for the overall experience.  I don't know why, I just love this place...
author: Matt G.

description: This is a favorite of mine, although I'm rarely there due to it's location, anyways this is one of the few old time bars left in the city, it could be classified as a dive, but I think it's just old and original, and the best thing about it the place is they keep a wheel of cheese on the bar, so instead of getting peanuts or popcorn, you get cheese and crackers, and since the way to my heart is through cheese, I love this place.
author: JIll H.

description: i'd return again, but maybe not on a quiet weeknight between christmas and new years.  appeared to be a true san fran dive tucked conspicuously across the street from citylights books and attended by writers, their families, travelers and regulars.  small but respectable beer selection.  gotta love a place where the decor and fixtures though not necessarily authentic artifacts when first installed are through age and dust becoming historical markers now.  come for the cozy, inebriated and open-minded chatter.
author: Jen J.

description: There is a point in one's life, maybe after they've read and reread On the Road obsessively, or maybe after they've discovered how meaningful life is after a mushroom sunrise on Mount Tam, when the Twelve Adler museum seems more magical. But on an average night, after you've long tired of the modern day Columbus/Broadway nightmare, the nostalgia is not quite enough to sustain enthusiasm for surly service and average beverages.
author: Megan W.

description:
I was behind a gentleman who asked for a round of Irish Car Bombs. 
Now, most bars I've been to lately don't do these drinks for one reason or another, so I didn't think much of it. The bartendress said, "I don't do those." Then he asked for the makings of a car bomb, just separate. She obliged for some reason.
The gentleman sat next to me and he and his party proceeded to drop the tumbler full of Baily's into their Guiness, splashing a little and complaining about how if she'd just given them shot glasses, there would be no mess. 
Two minutes later, she storms over with a rag in hand and reprimands them for doing the carbombs. "On good faith I gave those to you, and now look at what you did. It's disgusting, its gross. It's a mess I have to clean up." The whole party sat there wide eyed like 5th graders being yelled at. The man stammered an apology and she responded with something like "YEAH, WELL."  After she left the guy wondered aloud, "Well..why did she give us the makings for a car bomb then..?"
Good point. And sure, they were jerks for making a mess. But they paid to make a mess and to drink their drinks in an unhumiliated fashion.
If this is how customers are treated, I'm not entirely sure I want to return to this bar. Which is a shame because it's nicely lit, there's a piano in the back, there are neat old dusty things on the walls..I'm pretty much afraid to return lest I incur her wrath by spilling my beer somewhere.
author: Addyline L.

description:
if this bar were a person, it would be some retired career bureaucrat who rents a dvd of "the last waltz" to remember the good old days when he saw The Band play.  places like chevy's, bennigan's, etc. stick a bunch of cheesy crap on their walls, too; the cheesy crap on spec's walls is just dirtier.
i like dirty bars, and i like poorly lit bars, and i like bars that aren't completely populated with addle-brained scenesters and other douchebags, so this place is ok.  six dollars for a tiny little jameson and soda brimming with ice isn't too cool, though.
author: Mynameisdavid M.

description: Cooky little joint indeed. Bad news first, the beer selection kinda sucks and I saw some roaches. Now for the good stuff: The bar was really cool on the inside. The bar is decorated with all kinds of funny bumper stickers and other items. Your drinks are served by people who obviously care about your satisfaction. The space is dark and comfy.
author: Eric G.

description:
When I walk around North Beach, I always end up either here or Vesuvio, located right across Colombus St. after all...  I like the atmosphere with yellow lamps which adds retro kinda feeling to my sight.  

But am I the only one that feels there are too many rednecks here sometimes?
author: T T.

description: Recommended to me by a former San Franciscan and one of the coolest bars I think I've ever been to. It's dark, it's simple and a little hard to find for an out-of-towner (it's kind of in it's own little nook), but it just has that comfortable feel. This would be my first stop in the event I end up in San Francisco again in the future.
author: Art Q.

description: Specs does not like loud happy people. A few weeks ago I walked in with about 10 of my closest friends and as soon as we were loud and disrupitive they 86ed us.  They obviously don't cater to groups of people that like to talk.  If you're alone and want a bar and don't want to cause trouble it might be ok.
author: Brian B.

description:
A pretend dive-bar that has long rested on it's reputation (like Vesuvios). The head bar-person is obnoxious and not even in a friendly curmudgeon kind of way!  He is just rude and devoid of wit. 'Highlights' include a bad (flat) beer choice and moldy cheese.I guess this place is OK if you're a yuppie and you want to get insulted, but otherwise avoid like the plague!
A fake-dive for those too damned scared to drink in the 'Loin.
author: Matt E.

description: Poor Specs.  I guess North Beach didn't always suck.  It used to be a fun place, so Specs settled in there.  Little did it know that one day its home would be overrun with douchebags and baguettes.  But it was too late to move.  Specs just has to sit there and take it.  Mind you, it mainly has respite from those types during the week, but they ruin Specs weekends without fail.  Some come to Specs during the week to make it feel better about itself, and let it know that it's not Specs fault that it sucks two days a week.  It's just a victim of geography, but cool kids still love it just the same.  They just can't be around it when Specs is being taken advantage of by people who don't deserve to drink.
author: Coco D.

description: What's not to like about a great bar with Jamesons rocks (my drink here for some reason) (and at 15 Romolo) (different drinks for different bars), and cheese at the bar.  As in, a great wheel o' cheese.  When I first moved to SF lo these many years ago, I'd go out every Wednesday night (um, I still do), and this (and the Noc Noc) were standard stops.  They are as great as ever.  Old school is good school, as I'm fond of saying.  At least, my old school.  (Then again, I'm in need of rules to impose certainty on an uncertain world.  Like certain bars are great bars.  There's right, and there's wrong.  Rules like that.)
author: Laurel B.

description: The address is officially 12 William Saroyan Place- type that in, and you'll find the right map (otherwise you'll end up in Visitacion Valley!).  Adler is what the street/alley used to be called years ago, and apparently it's still valid as an alternate address.  It's a good place for simple drinks, but as my friend put it, 'it's not the place to get a pink grasshopper.'
author: Rego S.

description: I went here after my boyfriend's work Christmas party, with about ten coworkers. We were already drunk and Specs was very welcoming, excepting only for when one member of our group insisted on howling. It's divey like everyone says, which is a welcome thing in the craziness that is North Beach. I enjoyed it, but beyond that, nothing special...
author: Cyrelle D.

description: I'm rating last night's experience, not the bar. Love this place, been going for 15 years. Last night I brought a big group in, where we drank for 3 hours and tipped well. Guess we were being a little too loud, because without warning 3 hours in, the surly female barkeep we'd been tipping so well threw a handful of ice at us. Pretty funny yes, but also pretty damn uncalled for. I went over and talked to her, she admitted it, didn't apologize. I told her it would have been cool just to tell us to keep it down rather than throw ice, but she disagreed. We left. Definitely put a bad taste in my mouth on this place, which is a bummer, because I've loved drinking there over the years. Not a good way to treat your customers, specs.
author: Ben F.

description: Weird but entertaining dive bar on Columbus Ave. My favorite item of the "museum," hands down, is the epic battle between the python and the mongoose--stuffed, dried, and frozen in time within a Plexiglas-guarded case. There is a bunch of other crap too but that's got to be the coolest item of random in there. Bar serves beer, drinks, and caters mostly to old men with long beards.
author: Kelly R.

description: Sure, they haven't dusted or mopped in 10 years, but that's what gives this place its charm.  Bartenders are no-nonsense, and the crowd runs from former beat poets to young locals to girls just getting off work from Centerfold's.  In other words, it's a perfect cross-section of San Francisco.
author: Geoff K.

description: Like Vesuvios but more real.  I like to think of it as the real beat hang out.
author: Alexis M.

description:
dig the joynt. its always been a favorite slide by later kinda place esp. with the types who're always bashin' no. beach. if you can get the seats to the right as you walk in, you get the benefit of an expansive view of the myriad of kooks at the bar and the freaks moving in and out for a butt. the bartenders are well worn old hands, look beyond their years and seem to emanate that 'what I've seen, you wouldn't believe' vibe. you just want to ask them a question and get em rolling. 

its a good place for bud on tap, just feels like you'd be overdoing it otherwise.
author: tommy p.

description: One of the best bars around. They have a limited selection and the bar staff doesn't seem to give a shit. But there's something about the atmosphere that keeps bringing me back...could be just the booze talking. There's often some drunk foreigner who will chat you up, the crazy old Asian dude looking for 'sexy sexy' and a hobo waiting outside to sell you some art. Good times!
author: Colleen B.

description: Dive bar that tries to hide from the beaten path. Great place to hit when you've already drank too much.
author: Chris S.

description: Not a great bar, but pretty cool inside. Think divey with a bit of old-timey and just a hair of voodoo. Very weird place. Still, having said that if I'm in the area I'll always stop in for a drink.
author: michael c.

description: This bar is the definition of "mixed bag." Always a random crowd,  I have had ice thrown at me by the bartender, and a pizza bought for my friends and I from a firefighter. Cheap pitchers.
author: Sara B.

description: A friend and I were convinced into going here while at the superior bar Vesuvio across the street by two strange Italian men. A homeless man interjected as we read the blurb about the bar outside before entering (that declared it "the place to go to write poetry or a great novel"). A trip to the bathroom introduced us to a disheveled woman rinsing a bouquet of roses while waiting in line for the toilet. The people who were here were characters, all right, as the bartender appeared drunk and haggard as he overreacted at our knocking an empty glass over (though not breaking it). The drinks were in small, toy-sized glasses and it was comical to watch grown men drink cosmopolitans. The people in attendance were interesting, but more in appearance than conversation. Perhaps a novel would not be the best thing to write here, as this joint yields better material for a stand-up routine.
author: Kristin L.

description: Awesome sailor's bar.  Ok, so there's not many sailors here any more, but you can come in and pretend you are one.  Worth coming just for the awesome stuff on the walls.  It attracts tourists, but it's not really that touristy, it's just damn authentic.  What more can I say?  A must-stop for lovers of old-fashioned bars.
author: Wes M.

description: This bar is from a different era, and that's why I like it. It's part gold-rush, part beatnik, part world war two, part speakeasy and it feels like you are inside a twisted wood cabin. I think it may derive from the lantern lighting. Hidden behind Tosca's, across the street from Vesuvio's, it makes one feel like it is your own secret bar.
author: Netty L.

description: I like that Specs is hidden from view, thus escaping the crowded, loud atmosphere of North Beach on a busy night. I also like it's unique collection of artifacts, posters and pictures. I like that you can order cheese and a big ole basket of saltines for $4.  I'm not sold on the price:size ratio of the mixed drinks. I know North Beach serves up notoriously small cocktails, but c'mon.. Specs has a different vibe and a different clientele, they should subvert the dominant paradigm!  Small, casino-sized cocktails with tons of ice cost at least $6 a pop before tip.  I also noticed that there was only one bartender working on a busy Saturday night. This made for slightly slower service.
author: Jenni D.

description: Why do I love Spec's? First, they have a gigantic wheel of cheese on the bar that they cut with some huge medieval knife. Two, it's a museum you can drink in. Third, they have the best Irish Coffee I've ever had, or, at least, the most serious Irish Coffee I've ever had. This is the kind of place where you can sit and drink and feel completely comfortable and content.
author: Melissa J.

description: I used to live right Specs and it was a perennial favorite for an old school bar experience- less sexual posing and more honest drinking.  Biggest cheapest martinis in San Francisco.  Yes it has some tourist elements but it is just weird enough to be truly funky.  Don't take any high maintenance friends there unless you're both looking for a place to smoke indoors.  The cheese looks odd but is really good.
author: Margaret F.

description: This is a stellar locals bar in North Beach tucked in a little side nook off the street, Spec's is a great place to have a beer and hang out for a night. You gotta love those wood bars that have the same kind of random item decoration you'd see in a Chili's or TGIF's. Now keep in mind, it's places like Spec's that did this all years and years before those craptastic chains got going. Random signage? check. Historic artifacts? check. Beer? check. What's not to love. Have dinner in North Beach and stop in for drinks, you'll thank me.
author: Andy A.

description: One of my favorite hidden bars.  The vibe is tranquil but warm and alive.  Perfect place to relax in the fast paced city.  Enjoy an Irish Coffee when it is cold and catch up with an old friend.
author: Shiho F.

description: Great place to hang out with other bitter single friends on Valentines Day. There was hardly anyone there and the drink were super cheap. Good if you wanna go grab some beers and actually be able to hear what your friends say.
author: Erin F.

description: Specs is kind of tucked away in a corner and can easily be missed, but if you do spot it you should step in.  It is a great place to start the night.  It has a relaxed atmosphere and plenty of room to sit around a table and chat with friends.  There are plenty other bars located nearby to check out once you are finished here.
author: Carly W.

description: coolest bar in north beach.... and i really dont care much for north beach. Bit of a hidden spot off the main drag from the rest of the north beach fan fare. Diverse crowd, chill vibe, very cool decor and ambiance.
author: Kelle K.

description: Just a good old bar but a solid one to spend time over a drink and conversation without all of the bad attitude and snooty bull you encounter over at Vesuvio's.  These guys win every time.
author: MJ M.

description: Very cool, old school kind of dive. Seems very mobby, and we've definitely seen some guys wearing spats and packing heat while sipping on our cocktails. Watch what you say in there!
author: Mariangela S.

description: I can't explain it. Why or how I end up at this place when I'm in SF and end up having a fantastic time???!!! It's totally a dive, completely random and completely hidden off on a side street. I simply can't explain it. If you like a place to avoid all the chaos of North Beach head here to have a cocktail. Cocktails are very reasonable and strong.
author: Jessica S.

description: My boyfriend's favorite bar. I like that it's kind of out of the way. People formed a makeshift band outside and were playing an accordion, a guitar, a drumset(?) and a banjo. That was pretty rad. The clientele kept to themselves and weren't there to be loud idiots on a stag night. I got to chat with an old biker dude who had some awesome SF stories. The bartender got us drinks, even gave my friend a triple when he ordered a single. She wasn't sitting around chatting us up, but she was busy & I don't need bartenders to pretend I'm their best friend anyway. I liked the atmosphere, excited to go again!
author: Ljótur H.

description: Part of the Beatnik trifecta of Tosca and Vesuvio, The Adler Museum is a strange little nook tucked into an 'alley' that is really just a cyst that has grown out of the sidewalk on the east side of Columbus.  Filled with various ephemera such as old signs, pictures, and dioramas, Adler's is almost like a museum that serves stiff drinks.  The music isn't bad either, and the bar is nice, and inexpensive.  Three drinks (a vodka tonic, a screwdriver, and a Trumper Pils) came out to $15, which is pretty good in my book, even if Adler is a touch divey.  Also cool to see Lo Pan, or a guy that looked just like him, kicking it in the bar with a guy wearing an ascot.
author: Eric M.

description: Jeez, why do i like this place so much?  Is it  because it smells, terrible like an old bar should? Is it because of all the bizarre and sublime  bric-a-brac on the walls?  Is it because it's the only North Beach watering hole that isn't crowded during Friday happy hours?  Is it the fontina cheese and saltines available for purchase and consumption? Or is it just because they provide cold beer in pitcher form after a hard day at the cube?  I gotta crush on you SPECS and it ain't puppy love.
author: Ryan D.

description: Favorite bar in North Beach / Chinatown area (note: not Nob Hill) to get away from the North Beach / Chinatown area. No nonsense. Get some beers from the groggy bartender and huddle around a wooden table.
author: matt c.

description: Played UNO there last night...met some totally sweet people. Got yelled at by the bartender, but made the bond with my new pals totally stronger. Ate the cheese and crackers again - totally delish.
author: Katy A.

description: I totally dig Spec's. They serve Chartreuse here, one of two bars in the city that I know of. Since I'm fond of Chartreuse, and not fond of trashy, overpriced, touristy bars, Spec's is the bar for me. It's comfy, dark, and they know how to pour a Guinness. The Fontaine cheese is great, the ambiance is mellow, unpretentious and friendly. Hands down, my favorite bar in the city. The decor alone is worth the trip!
author: elizabeth d.

description: Argh Matey. . . .that's what I think when I walk in.  Feel like I'm back in the Moby Dick era with sailors smoking their pipes, playing cards and talking with foreign accents.  Okay, so I have an imagination, but that's the Pisces in me that I can't help.  Hidden in a semi-alley, where its quiet, not routy, loud or over complicated.  Just an old school bar with old wooden floors, trinkets all over the place, full bar and a bunch of old timers that you can tell, are regulars there.  I'm sure they have great stories to tell, but some, you can tell by their facial expressions.  They're saying, don't talk to me, don't smile at me. . . I'm just here to drink alone, period.  Definitely intriguing to me.  I love to analyze those type of loners and create a story in my head on why they are such a grouch.  They have board games there too and prices are decent.  Definitely a hidden gem to scope out if you're within North Beach and Chinatown.
author: Janice F.

description: I have been 86'd from this place before after drinking too many shots of Bushmill's, then went straight over to the Bow Bow and had a total blast.  What a dive!!  If you hate this place then you are a dork.  For real.  Negatrons will never change, so stay far far away if you don't like real people and real atmosphere, and real shark teeth.  Whatever happened to the lady that reads palms?  I miss her.
author: Barbra K.

description: Apparently San Francisco natives were created here. Admittedly, the parents of my friends got laid here years ago. Why stop now? I say this little, heritage north beach bar should carry on the tradition. With the cheap drinks galore, perfect setting (surrounded by our uber-classy Broadway strip clubs), and of course the San Fran crowd, you have the perfect elixir for some new-baby-makin evenings. Get busy folks!
author: Rada I.

description: Spec's, I will never forget you. If you ever get the chance to talk to Sean, ask his about the 70s. Some of the best stories you will ever hear about San Francisco.
author: courtney t.

description:
i like specs a lot, and it is one of my favorite bars to go to enjoy a few drinks and to carry out an (hopefully) enjoyable conversation. as i have mentioned before, i don't typically go out to bars in an effort to meet new people, but rather like to spend time with a few close friends. this bar is very conducive to that. and if you DO have the urge to talk to strangers, this is also a great place to meet more than one interesting character. the crowd is generally older, but i could care less.

if you find a lull in conversation you can let your eyes case the joint and take in the miscellaneous memorabilia covering the walls. it's also fun to read the changing messages written on the outside chalkboard display. 

also: the bartenders are all terribly nice.

i wouldn't mind living in north beach, and if i did, i could see specs becoming my regularly visited week-night bar. it's perfect for a mellow evening soaked in whiskey and chit-chat.
author: Kayla K.

description: I definately reccommend this little place. It's got a really good vibe, hidden from the immediate street. The inside is decorated with a ton of stuff, and is lit to suggest that at some point the hobbits stopped here for a drink on the way to mordor. Also appropriate for the people up front playing magic: the gathering. All nerdy-ness aside, this is a great place for groups as there's several tables as well as the bar. We went on a Monday night, and it was fairly empty, but I hear from some friends of mine that it's a great place for a Friday or Saturday night. Cheers!
author: Stephanie D.

description: Specs is a fun little bar hidden right of the main Columbus St. drag - all the locals I bring here always say "wow - I didn't even know this place existed". Even at their busiest its never really "too busy". You can usually grab a table and a drink without too much trouble. This plus the fact they have CHEESE (alas, not free though), plus all the awesome and/or crazy stuff they have all over the walls makes it the perfect spot to hang out and recuperate before hitting the craziness that is North Beach again.
author: Jeff S.

description: I could have sat in that booth all night.  There is just a nice feel to this bar that made it hard to leave.  It makes you feel like you are in someplace special -- where things used to and still happen.  Very Romantic San Francisco ideals I guess.  One more reason to think about moving to North Beach someday.
author: Johanna w.

description: Another North Beach Classic, this place is charming.  One of the last places to actually display a sense of the Barbary Coast.  Appropriately located across from City Lights and Vesuvio, and next to Jazz at Pearls and Hustler's back door, Spec's is a throw back bordering on Nostalgic, like fisherman, bums and beatniks used to party here as kids in the mission think they party now.  Laid back, but not a drunkards bar, though it looks like they may have been there decades ago.  They have cheese and crackers for you, interesting reading selection, and the requisite scary bathrooms for every bar  in north beach.  Again, it just adds to the charm.
author: Christian W.

description: For that one perfect night when we got the round table right next to the honky tonk piano and drank Manhattans (or were they Old Fashioneds?).
author: Saskia v.

description: Spec's is a great dive that has been around FOREVER! It's sorta hidden in a little nook next to Jazz at Pearl's. Sean, the Scottish guy behind the bar, has a million great stories to tell, and he makes a MEAN Old Fashion! During the week, they set out baskets of old postcards sent from sailors, etc. during WWII "looking for the American Dream." Get a basket of cheese and crackers and try the Hefeweizen!
author: Nicole S.

description:
beer. i like it. and they have great selections. case closed!

(oh yeah - the history and the pictures and the bar stools and the kooky captions of weird items on the wall also make it pretty entertaining too. i feel like i'm going through a time warp when i step into this place.)
author: Jenz y.

description: I've lived in the area as well as worked basically around the corner from here for over 5 years  and visited last week for the first time. Had a girl date with the SF BFF and suggested we just walk from work. I asked if she ever went to specs ad shed never heard of it. So we wandered over. Um, outside patio is cute, then you walk inside and its a smelly dive with old adventurer type stuff on the walls (we compared topossibly what indiana jones would put on the wall, but not so amazing). We sat down and both being winos asked if they had a wine llist and immediately were embarassed that we did. No wine list one red or one white - ok two reds it is. then my buddy asked if they might have any food or snackies - cheese and crackers was her reply. Again we just confirmed our being out of place and new to the joint. But she brought us some snackies and we were good for the night. there was a random mix in the bar had we of stayed for a few hours I'm sure we would have made some new friends as there's not pretension in the air at all.
