But we left after our glass-o-red, but i did leave thinking that I've gotta bring my dad back here, he'd love it and wander around looking at all the treasures and signage around the bar
author: Audrey V.

description:
Yeah, live within walking distance of North Beach area and rarely go there, but one night we ended up at Specs and it was a pleasant surprise.

Would go back and bring friends.
author: James S.

description: what i like about this bar is they pour a stiff drink. we had $6 vodka tonics too small for my liking but the bartender we had poured the glass nearly full with vodka then a heavy splash of tonic. when we go over to north beach we will usually stop in here for a drink or two. i like the way it feels inside. good mix of people. maybe i would feel different if i had to deal with the bartender with attitude. never met or been there when he was.  tourists and locals go here which i like. i don't have a problem with tourists as some do. not sure why one would have problems with that. i get to talk up our city and hear about them and where they come from. then move on.
author: roger b.

description: One of my favorite bars in the city.  The beer selection isn't fantastic but it's good enough, and the atmosphere is as good as it gets.  It's a dark hovel filled with bizarre crap and eccentric locals.  If you're into dark, charismatic watering holes, this is the spot.
author: Barry Z.

description:
Ah...good ol' Specs.

Every memory i have of this place is a fond one...(and for the ones i don't have, i thank the bartender).  Certainly not the hot spot for the hipster set, but thus is the basis of it's appeal.  Specs is the consummate 'neighbourhood watering hole'--where everyone seems to know everybody else (in a completely unpretentious way), most of the crowd are aging North Beach denizens, gossiping and swapping armchair radical politics and conspiracy theories...like a doughnut shop that sells booze.  Frequently you'll find the resident pianoman playing ragtime in the back, and there's usually a jam session composed of patrons, neighbours and the occasional bindlestiff nursing a Steelie out front.  Perhaps it's the quirky decor (the '12 Adler Museum' itself) that gives the crowd something to aspire to.  Strange maritime artifacts, masks, stolen signs, a quasi-Egyptian sarcophagus with moving eyes and spectacles cover the walls, and draw the gaze of many a drunkenly lazy eye.  My favourite:  the sign above the bar notifying patrons, "We reserve the right to serve refuse to anyone."

Another of Specs' finer qualities is that steady business from neighbourhood regulars removes any need to tolerate bullshit from the bridge-and-tunnel fratboys/meatheads that make North Beach a rather miserable place on Friday/Saturday nights.  On more than one occasion have i been in Specs and seen loud, overweight twenty-somethings in "Frisco" hats walk in smelling like the strip club they just left, only to be tossed out in no uncertain terms by the bartender.  "Spring break's over, asshat, better go back to Concord."

A word about Specs himself, the bar's owner and namesake.  He bought the bar in 1968 (it apparently used to be a lesbian speakeasy), and he's been among the most adored neighbourhood personalities ever since.  Known for his generosity and quick-witted deadpan, Specs also hosts an annual celebration in honor of the man who saved his life.  Practically the whole neighbourhood shows up, and lots of people bring food to share.  The result is an impressive spread, and everyone's first drink is free.

Definitely the place to rub elbows with the locals...definitely NOT a tourist place...
author: J. Brandon L.

description: OK, sure, I'm there as a tourist alright? Though it's not as though I'm exactly new to the place. First discovered Spec's when I stumbled down the stairs from the Garden of Eden above looking for the john. Figured it was some sort of den of iniquity at the time (this was about the early 70's, my how time flies) and didn't really put it together as "Spec's" until a friend "Art" took us there in '79 and introduced us to Gary Snyder (who was mildly underwhelming btw). Anyhow, tho not a native of The City, I make it a point to check -up on the esteemed establishment every few years when I return to The City as a tourist. So come the last day of February I'm showing my sweetie the sights and 12 Adler is on the list. We pull up a couple stools at the bar, you meet a better crowd that way, and the first thing I notice is how clean the place is, someone has actually spiffed the place up. Same funky stuff on the walls, just now it's not covered in smoke-crusted dust. Strike up a chat with the local guy next to us and he introduces us to Lucy who's tending bar (manager maybe). Lucy is one sweet lady, friendly, welcoming; who later in the evening actually buys us a drink to celebrate my companion's first trip to The City as a real grownup. Now, how nice is that? During the course of the evening a gentleman started playing the piano in the back, looked to be a customer, and laid down some sweet licks, old show tunes just smooth as silk. Anyhow the vibe is easy-going, funky, warm, friendly; just a nice, relaxing place to hang. And Lucy is real class. I'd give it 5 stars, but I don't want you to think I'm 'just a tourist'. Maybe not quite the place to carry on and flout your hubris, perhaps you can find that on down the street.
author: gary S.

description: specs won my heart the first time i stepped through the doors and was overwhelmed by the sea-faring ephemera on the walls and ceiling. one of my favorite things is going for a walk up telegraph hill, winding down through north beach and then capping off the daytime stroll with an early evening drink at specs, perfection!
author: rachael s.

description: It's good to still have a place like Spec's around.  A barroom that lives up to the very definition: "a room or establishment whose main feature is a bar for the sale of liquor".  But along with this simple purpose, Spec's provides an atmosphere where the people and conversations flow as simply as the drinks and once you enter, whatever your station may be outside, you're just like everyone else on the inside - a barroom patron, there for a good drink and some honest conversation.
author: greg d.

description: Just for the record, it is spelled Specs', not Spec's. I think Specs is great. To me it is a welcome oasis of relative calm and genuine SF flavor in a swirling ocean of douchebaggery that is presently North Beach. I dig the lighting, the furnishings, the museum, and everything else about the joint except for the occasional clients who really don't appreciate Specs' like summa you oblivious types. First, off, for those of you who complain that the bartender asked you to quiet down because he/she did not appreciate your rendition of 'We Will Rock You,' ease up - house rules. There are plenty of bars where you can do that (Marina Sports Bar comes to mind). Also, this is a professional drinkingman's bar, not a place to order douchey frat drinks. Stick to beer, whiskey, and simple mixed drinks. Irish car bombs are for douches and probably don't go over that well with the Irish bartenders. I know a lot of you like places to be super loud so you feel that you are important, but Specs' really isn't the place to see and be seen. It is the eye of the hurricane; it is a place where you can take a book and even write a bit if you want to. There are plenty of establishments where you can bray like a donkey and "get stupid," (Blondies comes to mind), go there. Leave Specs alone and let us who enjoy it the way it is, continue to enjoy it.
author: Christopher V.

description: This was stop # 4 or the birthday pub crawl for one of my friend's, but it was actually the only stop that I made. It is located off of Columbus in a tiny alley. Look it up before you go. Didn't know what to expect and was pleasantly surprised. On this night, there were a few people playing guitar outside the front door. When you go inside, it is dimly lit and there's a lot of random stuff on the walls. Most notably, a lot of old time nude women photos. There's too much random stuff to mention, you just have to see it for yourself. There's a piano in the back with a piano man playing tunes. My friend did get him to play happy birthday for her. Another nice thing about this place is that you don't get the feeling that you should order a certain drink or look a certain way to be here. You can just show up and hang out. I'm sure there's a lot of places like this, but, it was more apparent here. Anyway, minus 1 star for cash only. I
author: Andrew Y.

description: The best bar experience I have ever had was at Spec's. and I have been to a lot of bars. I have been going to Spec's for about five years now, and about a year ago I was in there with my boyfriend and while we were sitting at a table drinking a little man was busily spinning colorful, metal, toy tops on his table. He must have had about twenty of them. Then he started scrawling in his sketchbook. Meanwhile the hunched, well dressed, man with a beak, whose name I always forget, came and began to play ragtime music on the piano. Then a drag queen in a blue flapper's dress with a torn shawl began singing Edith Piaf to the piano player's music. She fanned herself with a lace fan that had spines missing from it. She looked like Katherine Hepburn after 40 years of heroine use. Then the little artist man got up and delivered a picture of my boyfriend and I that he had scrawled. About this time the drag queen stopped singing, and started arguing with the bartender. The piano man kept playing Edith Piaf. The bartender finally came, grabbed the belligerent drag queen by the arm, and they started to struggle with each other. Then out of the darkness from behind the piano a tall, beautiful black woman steps out and finishes the Edith Piaf song while the bartender pulled the drag queen out of the bar. It almost made me want to quit drinking because I knew I would never have such a lovely bar experience as that. I have had some that rivaled it, but not in the same genre. In short I would recommend this bar to magical people, and hope that yuppies, ignoramuses, and ultra-hipsters stay away. It's nice to go somewhere where there are old people in love, and drunks throwing their lives away.
author: Lindsey H.

description: Nice place to hang out and socialize. What more could you want?
author: Dustin Y.

description: this place is fab.  ill never forget this one time the when the bartender broke up a fight i was having with my boyfriend....classic...AWESOME local bar.  warm, cozy and social.
author: Laura J.

description: The Best! Simply the best...I've spent many a day at this locale. It's a great place to drink in North Beach, it's where all of the locals wet their whistle. Dive Bar Heaven!!!!!
author: Conspiracy T.

description: Spec's is my favorite bar. Most reviewers have covered all the bases so I will not go into great detail. Just know that this bar has unparalled atmosphere. The crowd is often an interesting mix of seasoned drunks, young hipsters, and the occasional, annoying tourist. GREAT BAR.
author: jason m.

description: Ah, another S.F. institution. You can meet anyone from sex workers to old drunks to the Russian mafia to tourists in this bar. The bartenders are generally pretty cool too. Not a bad pint of Guinness. Drinks are strong and cheap. Overall this bar has a lot of character, and none of the pretension in an area increasingly invaded by the "Who is your daddy, and what does he do" crowd. Crazy characters hang out in front too, sometimes selling art. I had one dude refer to me and my left-leaning, if not socialist, friends as "sadists". I'm not sure what prompted that, as my memory was a bit foggy due to the Whiskey and Anchor Steam, but I found that humorous. Also watch out for the old black guy with the dildo (not that he's dangerous, just frickin' hilarious).
author: Jeremy J.
